actuation-operation.summary:
A crucial step in the prevention of the coronavirus spread is to stay away from surfaces that are usually touched by everybody’s hands. Thus, we designed a hands-free door handle to be able to operate doors with your arm instead your hand.

Print the two parts and use four M4 screws to mount the adapter onto your door handle.

Wash your hands and stay healthy!

actuation-operation.title: Corona Door Opener
actuation-operation.summary:
New Version ist online:
I've done some optimizations in the erognomics and I made the difficult part that broke through a little thicker.
I tried to keep it as small and handy as possible, but it still lies better in the hand and you don't slip off so easily.

The door opener is the perfect companion in the fight against the corona virus.
It protects you from contact with bacteria or viruses.
With the hook you can easily open and close doors. The front recess has various functions. It can be used to lock or open toilet doors, turn keys or press buttons (for example, on public transport).

Hands-free door handle attachment based on CIMUPC's Arm Door Opener - COVID-19.

I wanted to make some size changes for our door handles so I recreated the design in freecad 0.18 to make modification easier.

The STL provided is for the exterior side of a right hand opening door. Print out a mirrored version for the interior side.

actuation-operation.title: Hands-Free Door Opener
actuation-operation.summary:
Materialise released a Handsfree Door Opener to help against the spread of the Corona-virus.
In my opinion the design wasn't optimized for FDM 3D-printers so I did a redesign.
Kuddos to their original idea, I just redesigned the idea so that the handle could be printed without support on any FDM printer in a shorter amount of time.
I print them in PLA using my Prusa MK3 in just 1h45min a piece.

Link to their door opener:
https://www.materialise.com/en/hands-free-door-opener

The door opener is compatible with a wide range of door handles with diameters from 18 to 22mm.
There are 3 different designs to be used with M3, M4 and M5 nuts and bolts.

Feel free to redesign the thing to fit your style of door handle.

Just add four 16mm long bolts and nuts and you can Corona-proof any door. A piece of rubber (cut up bicycle tires or old rubber glove fingers) can help avoid the rotation of the doorhandle.

Let's print as many doorhandles as possible and donate them to retirement homes, local supermarkets, ...
Together we can help flatten the curve!

A hands free add on for your regular door handle. Designed for ease of creation.

  • Simple design
  • Easy to print
  • Assemble using M3 bolts and some rubber

I used rubber from a bicycle tire.

hands-free door opener to help prevent the spread of corona virus

The original idea comes from this thing: https://www.materialise.com/en/hands-free-door-opener

But since I have no access to SLS printing, I decided to optimize this door opener for fdm printing.

Works best for 18 ... 22 mm diam door handles.

Mounting requires 4x M6 Nuts and Screws (approx. 20mm long)

Happy printing and stay healthy!

Hands-free opener for door L-handle 19mm without screws against COVID19:

  • L-handle diameter 19 mm,
  • No screws needed,
  • Simple design avaible for FDM without holes and fillets,
  • Source files in Solidworks 2018.

notouchchallenge

Simple, practical handle.
Just 3 printed parts, no glue, no screws.

  • Push handles
  • Pull handles
  • Turn keys
  • Retractable
  • Belt clip
  • Easy to wash

The pin is really tight, might need to be filed depending on your printer tolerance.

Instructions:
Insert a rubber band in the internal hook of the handle, attach the other hand of the rubber band to the hook in slinding part. Retract it and put the pin in place.

Rv2: sugested by ibdilbert, I added internal hooks to attach a rubber band to force the retract.

Version 2: The push hook is more "U" shaped, as requested by dhajjar and Rcdi

The rubber band is optional.

NoTouchChallenge

Inspired by other similar solutions (like: https://www.materialise.com/en/hands-free-door-opener) I created this concept for which you dont need screws, only 3 zip ties (max 5 mm wide)
It should fit most of the door handles.
If you need a special size / shape you can modify the STP file, or ask me.
If you need more info please contact me.

Print direction: see picture from CURA
Print time 2-3h depending on the settings, no support needed.

actuation-operation.title: Hands free door handle
actuation-operation.summary: I create this for office door to prevent spread of the viruses. You nead two zip tie. Interior dimmensions is 7x19mm.

I wanted to print something that helps during these turbulent times and which ideally prevents harm to people.

As we touch our faces quite often with our hands, it is at the moment very important to wash your hands regularly. However, you cannot wash your hands each time you open a door and also the door handle cannot be cleaned after each person.

So I came up with the idea of a printed part which allows to open the door without using your hand. It turns out that many people had a similar idea.

So I wanted to make a design, which has some advantages to the others:

  • only requires stuff that most people have at home (no screws or nuts, just zip ties and for example rubber bands)
  • universally applicable at the inner and outer side of the door and with a variety of door handles
  • very fast to print and install
  • just 1 part
  • no supports needed
  • explanation on how to use directly shown on the part (thx @materialise for the graphic)

actuation-operation.title: Hands-free Arm Door Opener
actuation-operation.summary:
Door handle attachment to open a door hands-free just using your arm.
I made designs for round door handles with 18 mm, 20 mm, and 22 mm diameter.

Hands-free door opener that helps you to preventa a direct contact with the door handle. This is a modified version of the original design by Materialise, which you can find here: https://www.materialise.com/en/hands-free-door-opener/technical-information

I made their design work with M3 nuts and bolts which are more common for 3d printing enthusiasts.

Stay safe.

Very simple hands free tool for your door handle.

Perhaps handy in Influenza and Covid-19 times.

But also handy when you have a door that you regularly have to pass with both hands fully loaded. One exaple is the door to your garage: it´s easy to bring your shopping goods into your house with that tool.

Just step in with one of your shoes, push down and push the door open with your shoe.

I have to say kids love it. Perhaps people who love horse riding will like it too ;D

You need a small robe or something. You can use a cable tie to fix it on the door handle.

Thx to my wife for the basic idea!

A door-handle mounted adapter for handsfree use of doors. Should help prevent direct touch of handles.

Versions for round 20mm and 22mm round handles.

You will need:

1x M5x16
1x M5x20
2x M5 Nuts

Additionally some kind of rubber pad should be used to prevent slipping of the adapter.

Inspired by the Materialise Hands-Free Door-Opener.

Still don't forget to wash your hands a lot, this is just another little helper.

actuation-operation.title: Hope'N Door - Hands Free Door Opener #NoTouchChallenge
actuation-operation.summary:
This is a collaborative project based on a chain of solidarity. This device was created to let the door´s opening with the forearm and avoid the spread of Covid-19 by bringing a “rainbow of hope” to our nursing homes.

It is a hands free door opener that would avoid the contact with hands when we open the doors. According to the information provided by the WHO, the contact with frequently used surfaces, such as a door handle, is one of the main ways of infection. We have to do something.

The set up is very easy and a couple of cable ties are enough to fix the device to any door handle. In addition, thanks to its universal design it is adaptable to different models and sizes of door handle.

For more information (instructions manual, videos, and much more) please visit:
https://nortpalet.com/en/info/hope-door/
This is the website where we have launched this nonprofit project. Join us!

PRINTING SUGGESTIONS:
Material: PLA (and others)
Infill: 15-20 %
Supports: No

actuation-operation.title: Print2Help Hands Free Forearm Door Handle Clamp
actuation-operation.summary:
Custom design of a door handle clamp which can be used to allow hands free opening of door by using the forearm, reducing common touch points for spread of infection.

The clamp can fit door handles from a minimum of 17mm diameter.

Requires 4x M5 round head machine screws and 4x M5 Nyloc or normal Hex nuts

Printed in PLA with 1.2mm perimeter and 10% infill and works perfectly.

actuation-operation.title: COVID parametric door handle - rectangular vertical type
actuation-operation.summary:
A parametric adaptation of the awesome door handle design by the materialise team found here:

materialise.com/en/hands-free-door-opener?utm_source=ALL+CUSTOMERS&utm_campaign=3ea0fa58dd-CORP-REG-Doormaster+3000+MAN-PRODUP&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_7544445bcb-3ea0fa58dd-%5BLIST_EMAIL_ID%5D&ct=t%28CORP-REG-Doormaster+3000+MAN-PRODUP%29&goal=0_7544445bcb-3ea0fa58dd-%5BLIST_EMAIL_ID%5D

Which allows you to open door handles using your arm instead of the hand.

We found that we needed lots of different sizes to equip our production centres and offices, which didn't always work with the original models, and so this parametric version was created. Please follow the video tutorial to modify the .f3d file in AutoDesk Fusion 360, available here:
https://youtu.be/lcrFheY1azg

N.B. There are 3 versions available for different shaped handles

actuation-operation.title: Springtail, A hands-free door handle mod
actuation-operation.summary:
Springtail is an open source door handle modification designed to reduce the spread of disease.

This is a work in progress, and major or incremental changes may take place based on user feedback

actuation-operation.title: 10,5 X 16,8 Elliptic Hands-Free Door Handle addon
actuation-operation.summary:
Takes an M4x16mm countersunk screw and M4 nut (nyloc is better).
I couldn't find one that fits my door so I made this. It seems to fit most of the doors with ASSA locks and handles built in the '80s.
Fits elliptic shape handles (h16.8mm x w10.5mm-ish).
I've built some compliance in the clamp shape so that it goes around the handle tail.

Printed in PLA with a 0.8mm nozzle @0.35mm layer height. Designed for 1mm wall thickness. (for printing with a 0.4mm nozzle slice with a wall thickness of 0.5)
Made for speed and functionality, not looks :-)
Print it on the side, no supports required. Prints in 50mns on my machine

Inspired by (but not copied from) the Materialise design found here https://www.materialise.com/en/press-releases/3d-printing-technology-supports-coronavirus-containment-efforts

A fairly straight-forward set of hands-free door handle attachments that allow users to open fairly common Australian door handles with 16mm shafts. Made one for vertical handles as well as the typical turn style handle.

Print on the 'Z' side. No supports necessary. I use 1.5x4.5x200mm zip ties to attach these to the doorhandle. Remix as necessary.

actuation-operation.title: Hands-free Arm Door Opener
actuation-operation.summary:
Door handle attachment to open a door hands-free just using your arm.
I made designs for round door handles with 18 mm, 20 mm, and 22 mm diameter.

Door Handle adapter for Arm opening
Adaptador de manija para apertura con el brazo.

constraint.summary:
Hi, this is my attempt to hopefully reduce the spread of the coronavirus or other germs, I call it the "Savegrabber".

It is a hook-like device that allows the opening and closing of doors without touching the handle. There is also a tip to press buttons in the elevator or light switches.
The touching surfaces are designed to be as small as possible, so the contamination should be low. My idea is to wear the Savegrabber with a retractable key chain on the belt or on a bag.
If everyone would use this, I think this could be an additional barrier to germs.
The print in PLA is sufficient and you can clean it using alcoholic disinfect.

So please print as much as you can and give it to others. If you have ideas to optimize - please do so. The Savegrabber has been designed in Fusion360. I produced also an stl file.
V2 is designed to be a bit stronger - print with triangular infill 55%.
UPDATE: now it has been designed more roundish and it should fit to handles in public transportation for diameter up to 31mm. This is the file savegrabber_rd.stl
UPDATE 27.3.2020: Because of some requests I uploaded also the Fusion360 File for the rounded version - Savegrabber_rd.f3d

Thanks for your feedback, and comments, I would really appreciate your donation.

Kind regards

Martin

constraint.title: Savegrabber - open door without touching the handle, (dont forget to donate;-)) press knobs without touching - additional barrier for the coronavirus and other  germs
constraint.summary:
I needed simple, aesthetically pleasing a non-permanent and no-drill solution to stop our 1.5 year old from opening lever doors in our apartment.

These stop the lever from pivoting down, and most children who NEED child safety devices, aren't tall enough to lift the lever high enough to disengage the latch. I now have them on all of our doors, and so does a family member. Working wonderfully so far.

I've tried them on a variety of brands and styles of lever knobs. So far I haven't come across one that didn't fit.

Left and right are included. I recommend placing it on the side most likely to be grabbed. Typically on the outside of the door.

Hex infill at 25% or more will suffice for strength if printing in PLA.

constraint.title: Childproof Lever Doorknob
constraint.summary:
We have lever doorknobs throughout our house, partially for accessibility reasons. While they're easier for me to open, they're also easier for our clever toddler (and apparently cats) to open. I looked around, and commercial systems try to prevent use of the doorknob completely and, if youtube videos are to be believed, they're ineffective at that. I didn't want something that could lock an occupant inside the room. This simple device blocks the lever from being pulled down, while still leaving it free to move up. Our short little toddler isn't big enough to push the lever up, so he's kept out, while us giants are free to pass.

This model is designed to fit a Schlage Flair with a round plate, but it'll likely fit many other models and brands. You may have to scale up a small percent if your doorknob backing plate is a different size.

Critical default dimensions (scale up or down as needed)
Maximum backing plate diameter: 29mm
Distance from door surface to back of lever: 47mm

Installation

  • Remove doorknob
  • Slide childproof device behind doorknob
  • Re-install doorknob, leave screws slightly loose
  • Rotate device so that raised portion is below the lever and the lever is just barely in contact with the raised portion
  • Tighten all screws
  • Test to make sure device doesn't slip. If it slips, tighten screws some more. If you can't get it tight enough for it not to slip, do not rely on lock for safety. Please remix and create some mechanism that prevents the device from slipping.

Alternative Mounting
Check out the remix by arundolon that uses an alternative mounting. For handles that have enough surface area, it allows you to install without removing the doorknob.

constraint.title: Cabinet Latch/Lock
constraint.summary:
Wanted some child safety locks for our lower kitchen cabinets as my 9mo daughter is starting to get handsy and curious.
There are two sizes, small and large.
These are printed flat with some supports for the latch part.

*I am not responsible if your child missuses these items or gets injured while near them.
Please use your own judgement when dealing with your child's safety.

actuation-operation.summary:
Tired of having to deal with wet toilet door handles? We sure are... (just to be clear, Prototype Asia is located in a flatted factory building with shared washroom for all tenants).

So we designed this screw-on handle that could be used to retrofit any latch free door, and transform it into a hands-free door.

It can also used as a regular handle for drawers or to place on the sides of heavy things you need to lift and move around often, like your 3D printer :-)

FYI, doesn't work with double sided tape.

Don't have a 3D printer, you can buy this on Shapeways
http://www.shapeways.com/model/2048668/sanitary-door-handle-foot-door-handle.html

This is a hands-free door-opener for doors that don't latch, like bathrooms in an office or public environment. You use your foot to open the door rather than grabbing the handle. I saw metal versions of these on many of the bathroom doors at Penn State this year and thought it was clever. With the COVID-19 pandemic currently ongoing, I thought some might find this useful.

The mouting holes are sized for #10 screws.

I created this hands free door handle to open a door in an office. The latch was already disabled, but you still had to grab the knob to open the door. This allowed the door to be opened easily with an arm. The hole pattern was designed to fit over two existing screws from the deadbolt. I added the 3rd hole, which needed to be drilled into the door, because it was developing a crack (See picture). With the 3 holes, this has lasted 4 months made from ABS with constant use.

This assembly will allow you to open and close doors without using your hands at all. To operate you simply push down on the foot pedal and that will turn the Doorknob, then you simply push or pull with your foot to open or close the door. This will reduce your exposure to contamination by not having to touch the doorknob. All files have instructions on how to print them in there filename, all parts are designed to be printed in the orientation thet they are uploaded at. Before printing it is important that you measure the width of your door and pick the appropriate Bottom Bracket. I have included the STEP files as well for others to download and edit if they would like to. This assembly will only work on doors that when you turn the doorknob on one side then the other side doorknob will turn as well, the majority of all doors will do this but I think that there are some doors that will not.

https://youtu.be/vzh_dnGHmBg

constraint.summary:
Nonlethal Door Stop Multitool

  • Optimized downside to Maximize the grip performance for holding the door in place, while on the other hand smoothly slipping in under the door when placed. If you want to add more-extra-ultra grip to the downside of the door stop you can use a rubbercoating. I tried the spray-on version of Plastidip and it works really great for this purpose.
    For your information, this is what I used: http://www.plastidip.de.com/produkte/plasti-dip-flussiggummi/
    And best of it: you can remove the coating easyly if you don't like the result. Probably you can find something similar near you in some DIY store, hardware store, home improvement store or in a shop for car supplies. I found it in an electronics store.
  • Buckled upside to hold the door in a firm and secure grip.
  • Extra Big hole (~42mm diameter) with Extra smoothly rounded edges to pull it out comfortably with 2 Fingers or even with gloves.
  • Safekeeping by hanging it over the handle of the door is possible for most doors due to the Extra Big hole. So you have it at hand in a door stop / self defense emergency.
  • Easier slipping under the door even with a small gap to the floor, due to smoothly rounded tip and optimized design of the downside of the tip (reduced size of the first to teeth).
  • Suitable for ~4mm-40mm gaps without scaling. (Just a guess based of the dimensions, to be verified in experiment. Could be up to 50mm max.)
  • Wall and handle protector. Put it behind the door to avoid slamming the door against the wall. (Try it with the round end facing the door, too. Depending on the size of the handle and the character of the floor this can give better results.)
  • Windows can be kept open with it, too. (Not talking about the software.) Try to put it in the gap at the hinged side of the window.
  • Optimized for easy printing on FDM machines (i.e. Ultimaker, RepRap,...). You should be able to print it without outer support, for details see the section instructions.
  • Childsave. It is big enough that it can't be swallowed and does not have sharp edges. If you print it with the right material it is non toxic, too.
  • Portable. It is light weight and has an Extra Big hole to grab and attach to things so it is really portable. If you want to transport it with your bike, you could just hang it around the handlebar. You could also attach a string and hang it around your neck for transport. If you transport it with your car you can attach a string to the hole and hang it around your rear mirror as an ornament, too.
  • No assembly needed. It is just one piece so you don't have to worry about a difficult and time consuming assembly. It is usable right off the printbed.
  • Customizable. You can add some rubber coating to the downside to adjust the grip needed to the floor and door you want to use.
  • Nonlethal self defense tool. Hold it with two fingers in the Extra Big hole and just think about it. If you know what a tactical pen is, you know what I mean. Probably this is the first tool you have at hand when the Zombies try to rush into your home... Update: I thought about it again and probably this is not such a good idea, because the Nonlethal Door Stop Multitool is nonlethal and the Zombies are already dead. Seems not to match. You could instead try to impress them with your printing abilities and try to involve them into some kind of communication about it. (It is even more probable that a Zombie will communicate with you about 3D-printing than the Nonlethal Door Stop Multitool will do any serious harm to him or her...) Caution: Update: As Gyrobot mentiond in the comment, there is a chance that the Optimised Nonlethal Door Stop Multitool could be lethal, too. You could bore someone to death with it. I wonder if this could work with the Zombie issue mentiond above....
  • You can use it as an ornament by hanging it around your neck. The rappers hung alarm clocks around their neck in the '80s, so why not?
  • You can use it to build a trap. Remove the handle of the door on the inner side, hold the door open with the door stop, attach a tripwire to the door stop. When somebody enters the room they release the door by the tripwire and the door closes. Works best with self-closing doors...
  • Use it as communication enabler. Just put it on your desk at work. Somebody will ask what it is. And whoosh, you are right in the middle of a 3d-printing discussion. Don't forget to print the Thing Tag. Just in case you are asked... http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:200571/attribution_card
  • Use it to test your 3d-printer. The Door stop is pretty easy to print, so the frustration factor should be minimal. And after printing you have something useful to play around with. And even if the print is not fully completed, it will probably work to stop a door. And failed prints tend to attract people, who ask you about it. A perfect print is good, but to induce communication a failed print is far better.
  • Use it as door stop this is what it is intended to be. And it works pretty well for this purpose.

  • Probably no one here reads so much text, so it seems not to matter so much what else I write here about the mere unlimited possibilities you have with this piece of plastics. But if you have more ideas about how to use this tool, you are invited to post a comment.

    Credits

    • The door stop was build from scratch and
      inspired by thing 144708, Stopper of door No2:
      http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:144708.
    • The description was inspired by thing 35518, Blockystar:
      http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:35518
    • and thing 35560, The Warble Wobble:
      http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:35560.
      Thank you for your inspiration.
      The design was developed in FreeCAD. http://www.freecadweb.org
      Thank you for making such a powerful software available to the public!

Thank you for visiting!
Chris

Remixes:

  • Remixed Non-Lethal Door Stop By arod24 [Amauris Rodriguez]:
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:368257

  • Door Stopper by alexhbaiu [Alex Hbaiu]:
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:563123

    Thank you for sharing your creativity!

Simple door catch to stop doors slamming.

I designed this little catch because I had a couple of doors that slammed closed when I opened windows for a through draft.

I've printed mine in ABS. First design has been in use for at least 4 months and is still going strong. V2 was a very slight redesign of the base plate for added strength if hit by vacuum cleaners.

Disclaimer:
Obviously this catch should not be used to keep fire safety doors open! Fire doors should remain closed whenever possible to prevent potential fires spreading.

I have a closet door that always closes on its own. I liked the original concept but it was not working for what I needed. It was far too small and the way the Female piece mounted was not going to work for a door of that size.

In the pictures I have provided a picture of the original, the larger one (200% larger), and my final finished female piece. Note: I did not edit the male piece, I just made it 200% larger to match the female.

It works better than I could have imagined. Enjoy.

This is a remix from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:398515

constraint.title: Door Bumper ( Pumpkin fish .... )
constraint.summary:
Universal Door bumper

This is a child safety equipment.

I recommend to print this part in flexible filament

I like sharing my projects, hope you enjoy with my designs.

Instruction

You can download the files provided for 40mm door / sliding door

You can customize your model online with button "open in customizer"
or download the scad file and openScad .

Please ask me if you need help / improvement / bug report

Security

I can not guarantee a misuse or any other malfunction whatsoever.

Test the products and see if the security is satisfactory,
To be operational you must choose a sufficient infill ~ 30-60% and a shell about 2mm.

The choice of your flexible filament greatly influences the print parameters of the piece. Choose a shell and adequate infill for your filament.

Hope you enjoy

constraint.title: safety lock for doors without screws
constraint.summary: safety lock for doors without screws

If you have kids, chances are they are ninja's just like mine. These little ninja's will get into anything and everything (including taking a sharpie to your white kitchen cabinets). I designed this device that slips over the door (preferably near the top) and locks the door within the door frame so that we can stop our little ninjas in their tracks. It also has a built in mechanism to prevent smashed fingers.

I've tested this with my 3 and 2 year old. It works great!

Let me know what you guys/gals think in the comments and/or if you would like to see modifications.

I plan to improve and come out with more child ninja safety in the future.

*Update: Added the .f3d file from Autodesk Fusion 360.

Update (10/23/15) - After a good solid month of use, I had one of these snap right in bend of the arm near the pet that latches onto the door. I'm working on a fix for for this to make it stronger.
Also, I have some changes that should help with the triangle part scratching the door frame. My print bed is jacked up so as soon as I get some new glass, I can test it.

Feel free to comment or PM me if you have any ideas on improvement.

https://youtu.be/iA1tRmMiJ1M

actuation-operation.title: Ninja Lock - Indoor Child Door Lock
actuation-operation.summary:
Make opening doors real easy with this lever style adaptor. It installs in minutes and is designed to work with a common Qwikset 1.875" (47.6mm) diameter round door knob.

To open door simply apply a downward force with one or two fingers and pull door forward. A knurled area provides a non slip grip.

A single #6 x 1/2 inch long sheet metal screw clamps the adaptor tightly to the door knob, it can be mounted for left or right hand operation.

Available in two sizes, small lever (-s) or large lever (-l), Solidworks files attached so you can modify it to fit any door knob.

actuation-operation.title: Doorknob Levers
actuation-operation.summary:
I was scheduled to have bilateral carpal tunnel surgery and wanted to have lever style doorknobs, so I created these levers to fit the doorknobs that are in my house.

My surgery was successfully performed on 10/22/15 and the levers were really helpful during the first few days of my recovery.

The 47mm lever has a slight taper to fit a "tulip" style knob. The 51mm lever has a more square profile to fit a flat style knob. See the pictures of my knobs for clarification.

The levers have a small lip on the inner edge of the hole to help keep the lever properly positioned on the knob, place the lever on the knob with the small lip out.

UPDATE - I just updated the levers to allow the screw to be on the top of the handle when installed on left-hinge doors - not upside-down like in my pictures.

actuation-operation.title: Door Knob Lever Adapter
actuation-operation.summary:
Recently, a friend of mine both broke of his wrists in a bicycle crash. On his first day home, someone came to the door while he was alone and he realized that he couldn't actually open the front door- or any other doors in apartment if they had been closed.

I took photos of the four different styles of knob in his apartment and printed up these levers. they weren't designed to be svelte, they were designed to be opened with a cast or a knee or whatever he could, so they are big, clunky, and have ends that are easy to hook onto for leverage.

I've included stl files of the knob shapes that I used as the boolean tool for each of the handle styles, in case that helps. The BaseHandle shapes fit no particular knobs, but you can model and cut your own door knob shape out of them if you like.

Here are the rough diameters of the different style knobs. They're all pretty similar, which makes me think that there's some kind of standard, and I'm just bad at measuring:

Ball: ~47.6 mm
Rounded: ~48 mm
Squarey: ~48.5 mm
Tapered: ~47 mm.

Each one requires 4 M3x16(ish) socket cap bolts, 4 nuts, and 4 optional washers.

updated almost immediately: I had the incorrect stl uploaded as TaperedKnob

actuation-operation.title: Sturdy Door Knob Lever, Customizable
actuation-operation.summary:
This is a customizable adapter to convert a round door knob into a door handle with a lever. It is a remix of my previous design, but adapted to be overall thicker and sturdier, to render 10 times faster, and to work with Customizer.

As before this is a smooth ergonomic design, so depending on your computer it may take a few minutes to render.

The most elegant resulting appearance is obtained if you match the nom_knob_diam variable in the .scad file to within at least 0.3mm of the correct diameter for your door knob. Calipers and good calibration are helpful for this, otherwise you may have to adjust and reprint. You can also try terminating a test print early, and using the first few layers to check your measurement. At the ideal size the nut and bolt sides will clamp together tightly right as it reaches the desired grip on the door knob. If you aren't getting enough grip to your door knob, try adding a very thin strip of poster putty around the door knob before clamping the lever on.

The example stl file is for a 54.9mm diameter door knob, and is designed to be held on with an M5x18 bolt and an M5 nut.

Note: The OpenSCAD file uses my threading library for creating the properly sized recessed bolt and nut holes. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1686322 The customizable version has the dependencies copied and pasted in since Customizer cannot yet load libraries.

Printed in ABS because this goes in my garage where it gets hot in the summer. Used 0.3mm layers and 50% infill to make it strong.
This is very convenient when bringing in groceries and only having an elbow free to operate the door knob.

This converts a round-style doorknob to a lever style. It fits many brands and styles of round knob. It's the perfect accessory for a touchless opening tool or if you need a lever for your foot-operated door opener.

This is also a component in my foot operated door opener, available here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4350774

Attach with two zip ties. I highly recommend that you use Gorilla Tape or Duct Tape on the inside for a stickier fit. To do so, tear off a 3 inch piece, roll it into a cylinder so it is double sided, and then attach to the inside of the 3D printed half. Repeat for the other half.

actuation-operation.title: Round Door Handle No hands Lever
actuation-operation.summary:
My house has Spherical/Round door handles. I wanted to make it so I can open them without any hands. There are a lot of these designs for lever door handles, but I found none for spherical door handles that are common in homes.

You will need to print two parts.
Door Handle Extension (fits around the door knob) Blue in the photo
Door Handle Accessory (the "Flap" part) Red in the photo

I have tested this on two brands of door handles of different sizes. Defiant brand door handles are 54mm in Diameter. Schlage brand door handles are 51 mm in Diameter. If you need to scale the Extension, you will likely need to scale the Accessory part too.

I was planning on make different "Accessory" flap parts, but this one seems to work for me. You can remix your own design.

*Important* In order to make these extensions not slip, I added a rubber band under the 3d printed part. You may need to do the same, unfortunately.

You will also need some M4 bolts. This is what I used. (sorry for the typo screw size)
1x M4 x 20mm
2x M4 x 8mm (These hole the Accessory and are threaded right into the holes of the Extension)
1x M4 Nut

*Update* I added three more sizes to accommodate if you need to add a elastic band or other grip material, try one size up from the actual handle diameter. So now there is 51, 52, 53, 54 and 55 mm spherical sized Extensions. If you need a different sized extension, let me know and I will see what I can do.

Open doors without touching round knobs with your hands. This is a simple design and quick fix for typical architectural door knobs. Use a tie-wrap to tighten on doorknob. There are two models. S- for knobs under 2" diameter / M - for knobs over 2" diameter. We recommend 100% infill for print settings. Feel free to download, modify and make recommendations. We are working on a 2.0 version (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4237806) with better door support structure. also a 3.0 version that does not need tie-wraps. Parallel to this we are working on a pull version too.

actuation-operation.title: Door opener
actuation-operation.summary:
Door opener, optimized for the ugly doors of the building where I live, for which I could find no suitable alternative.

Allows to perform without direct hands contact the 3 operations required to enter and exit the building: turn the cylindrical handle & push the (rather heavy) door, compose the door's digicode, pull the door.

I tried to reduce as much as I could the surface that can get contaminated.

The tool is made of two pieces, the "holder" part is specific to the door model of my building, and can be easily swapped. No need to glue anything, as long as your printer has a decently good calibration.

Meant to be printed with PETG, which usually has a good resistance to sanitizer products.
No need for supports.
I print this on a Prusa i3Mk3s with a 0.6 nozzle, draft settings, at least 30% infill to make it strong enough mechanically, and 0.3 mm layer height.

Feel free to use and modify it according to the license specified below.

I made this with Alibre Design / Atom 3D in about 1 hour total time, including 3 iterations.
Source files to be uploaded soon.

This is for adding an adapter latch to a round door knob so that you can open the door hands free. Covid-19 or other virus, germs transfer reduced, hopefully.

I got the basic idea from @adapta Adaptaio on MyMiniFactory. I've posted it there as well.

I modified design to allow for various knob sizes 2" and smaller, with a 3D printed squeeze clamping Latch, rather than the zip tie style.

I printed with Clear ABS on a Zortrax M200 at 90% fill and 0.09 mm layers, but up to 0.29 mm layer will work with a little clean-up of the holes. Support was added at 35% or more angle. Position the parts for printing to minimize support is recommended.

There is a Clockwise turn (CW) to open and a Counter-Clockwise (CCW) turn to open version of the main part, depending on the door type you have.

No hardware is required to install.

Caution when squeezing the clamping latch downward. If too tight to fully latch, rotate pin and move out 1 groove and retry.

If too tight, The pin will pop out of the Latch Handle Pivot points.

actuation-operation.title: Hands Free Door Opener - Foot Operated Door Opener
actuation-operation.summary:
Video: https://youtu.be/2Y6TB94vhrs

If you download this thing, please "like" or "add to collection." Check out my other designs here: https://www.thingiverse.com/tonyyoungblood/designs

Sometimes your hands are full, and you need to open a door! Sometimes there's a deadly pandemic knocking about, and you're afraid of germs. That's where the Foot Door Opener comes in.

Use this device to open doors with your feet. This works best in your home, not a workplace where heavy use could lead to breakage. Also not recommended for homes with small children.

You will need:

  • 8 feet of 1/8" rope.
  • Qty 8 of #8 or #10 screws, 3/4" long.
  • Gel superglue. I use Loctite brand.
  • 2 large rubber bands.
  • 4 zip ties, 6 inches or longer
  • Gorilla tape or duct tape

Instructions:

Is your door knob Round-Style or Lever-Style? If Round, print the file 1of1DoorKnobHandle. If Lever-Style, you won't need this file.

Print the files 1of2FootMechanism and 2of2FootMechanism.

If you already have a lever style door handle, skip the following paragraph:

Gather the two halves of the Knob Lever. Line the inside the halves with rolled-up Gorilla tape (to help reduce sliding) and place over your door knob. Depending on your door, the lever half may be on top or bottom. Secure each side with a zip tie. The tie slides through the holes. Refer to pictures. I slid my excess tie length back through the holes to prevent a sharp cut edge. If you like, you can tape over the ties to make the edges less sharp.

Gather the parts for the Foot Mechanism. Refer to Assembly guide and glue parts together. Don't accidentally glue the round pegs where they need to turn.

Affix the Foot Mechanism to close to the bottom of your door with the screws. Refer to video for placement ideas.

Take your rope and tie one end through one of the holes on the foot mechanism. I just passed it through the top of the hole and tied a knot to keep it from slipping through. See pictures.

Pass the other end of the rope through one of the holes on the Knob-Lever. I recommend trying the middle one first. Before you tie it off, turn the lever down as far as it will go. While holding it down, also hold down the Foot Mechanism as far as it will go. This is the length you want. Mark the rope and tie off the top. It may take several tries to get the tension just right. If you are using a Lever style door handle, you can just tie the rope around the lever and tape it.

Turn the knob on the other side of the door both directions. Make sure the Foot Mechanism goes up and down and does not prevent the door from opening when someone turns the other knob upward. If that happens, try a different hole in the Knob Lever.

Use the hole in the other side of the foot mechanism to tie a rubber band. Pass the other side of the rubber band through the small hole in the bottom of the mechanism. You want the tension to keep the sliding mechanism in its resting middle position. The rubber band prevents the mechanism from getting stuck at the top of its arc.

Press your foot down on the mechanism to open the door. To close the door, place your foot on the bottom part of the mechanism (not on the rotating part.)

Please let me know if you have any questions or if any of this is confusing.

NoTouchChallenge

constraint.title: magnetic drawer lock
constraint.summary:
This is a remix of the magnetic cupboard locks by user Non-ICE, however this design is made for use with pull-out drawers instead of cabinets/cupboards.

Additional hardware required per lock:
#6 x 1" screw or similar (x2)
8mm x 3mm cylindrical magnet (x1)

The thin profile allows for installation in between the drawer side and the cabinetry frame. Use a screw to attach the latch to the frame of the cabinet. Install a magnet in the hook using pliers to push it in if necessary, then use screw to attach the hook to the side of the drawer. Leave the hook screw loose enough so that the hook can pivot on it.

The hammer of the hook is pulled down by gravity to catch the latch. When a magnetic key is used on the face of the drawer the hook is pulled back off the latch allowing the drawer to open.

A small hole is provided in the magnet chamber to allow for removal of the magnet using a paperclip if needed.

Use any magnetic key design to open the locks (such as the one found here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2793122).

To temporarily disable the lock, lightly tighten the screw that the hook pivots on so that it can no longer pivot forward.

These have been tested on my kitchen drawers and work great at keeping my infant from opening them.

User datdiy's remix of the original design inspired these hook and latch changes.

constraint.title: Improved drawer child lock
constraint.summary:
Simple drawer lock designed to keep very curious little people out. Designed for an IKEA MALM chest of drawers, but it will likely fit other drawers with wood-based side walls (although if you're feeling adventurous and try to use this on a metal drawer, I'd be happy to hear about this).

Even though I've installed drawer locks (ikea patrull and my clone) in the clothes drawers, my 2yo still manages to make a mess by pulling out clothes through the small gap which is needed for the patrull-type lock.

The old lock has the fixed part attached to the front of the drawer, while the flexible arm is deeper inside the drawer. This requires the user to reach deeper into the drawer in order to unlock it, so the drawer needs to extend considerably before being unlocked.

This is a redesign of the lock, focused on minimizing the "locked" drawer extension. The fixed attachment point was moved deeper into the drawer, while the flexible arm extends towards the front. When attached properly, the locked drawer will extend by only ~15mm (or however large your finger is), which is enough to operate the lock.

The downside of this solution is that the lock requires considerably less force to operate. Don't tell my daughter :)

The lock is designed for installation on the left side of the drawer. A mirrored copy will fit the right

constraint.title: Child Proof Cabinet Lock
constraint.summary: I needed a simple lock for my single cabinet doors, so I designed this in Fusion 360. It provides a simple way to safely lock your cabinets so children cannot open them. It is a quick one piece print.

Pushbutton-activated child safety latch for wooden cabinets and drawers. Installs with a single #4 (2.5mm) screw and can be operated with one thumb. The mechanism is hidden behind the cabinet door except for the discreet release button. Prints quickly and without supports.

Releasing the latch requires first sliding the button to the right against a spring, then pressing down against another spring. That should be complex enough to thwart even a genius toddler.

Intended for cabinets that have a front face or front flange for the latch to grab (see illustration). If your cabinets have no front trim around the door openings, you'll need to embed a small screw inside the front edge of your cabinets (protruding about 5mm) so the latch has something to grab.

Optimized for PETG plastic (which retains the springiness of the springs over time), but other plastics will probably work at least for a while. If you use a more brittle plastic like PLA, be careful not to break the parts when assembling the sliding mechanism (see below).
use this in conjunction with childproof drawer locks/latches to completely childproof a drawer.

actuation-operation.summary:
Armie is a 3D printed hands-free handle, designed to prevent the spreading of COVID-19. The virus is said to live on hard surfaces for up to 72 hours, within that time many people may have touched the handles of the drawers or doors in your place of work. Armie promotes people to use their arms to open doors, as the user is less likely to transmit the virus using this method.

The device is designed to fit on most handle profiles, however, we are aware it may not fit onto all handles. Armie requires a minimum of two cable ties to successfully secure the 3D print to the handle. There is a left and right-hand version of the Armie, please print according to which side of the door your handle is situated. Installation instructions on how to install Armie can be found within the project folder.

Together we can help prevent the spreading of COVID-19. Please get in touch if you have any feedback regarding the design or how it could be improved.

printcity@mmu.ac.uk

PrintCity Team

This is my take on a door opening tool that will allow you to open public doors without using your hands. Although there are many existing designs, mine is somewhat unique in that the contaminated portion of the tool, folds into the handle, leaving your pockets clean and germ-free.

The tool also serves as a button pushing tool, useful for elevator buttons.

And when unfolded, the tool serves as a utility S-hook which you can use to hang purses or backpacks to keep them off the ground.

And lastly, the hook works as a bag carrier too.

The handle features a lever lock to keep the hook from folding unintentionally.

Assembly requires (3) M3x8mm button head screws, and (1) M3x6mm socket cap head screws. Also a little bit of cyanoacrylate (super) glue is required to secure the hinge portion of the tool.

I've included the sketchup source file in the file list.

constraint.title: cupboard Lock (baby Safety)
constraint.summary:

constraint.summary:
Do you have an inquisitive baby and a cupboard full of treasure? Then this item is definitely for you!

My design could be used on any cupboard with swing or sliding doors, where door handle is mounted with single screw. You need to remove original door handles though.

You could use screws from original handles if they are no longer than 20 mm. Right handle should be tightened to the cupboard door, while left should rotate. I would recommend placing spacer under screws head.

Two versions provided: 40 mm and 70 mm between mounting screws. Feel free to remix your own version, the 40mm have two parts, that could be pulled apart for longer designs.

UPDATE: Uploaded a 97mm version as per request. Also beefed up the stress area by 30%.

UPDATE: Uploaded 2 more versions that are longer than the original. The medium one is 1" longer than the original, and the longest one is 2" longer than the original.

This child safety lock is effective at keeping tiny hands out of where they don't belong. Please note that it is not a "one size fits all" lock. Refer to picture for sizing details and compare against your cupboard to see if it'll fit. You can probably scale both parts proportionately on one axis to make them longer, but do so at your discretion.

Print using the default orientation.

Please don't print this if you think your toddler will be able to figure out how to unlock it himself/herself. it requires two hands to operate simultaneously so it shouldn't be easy. By using this, you agree not to hold me responsible should your child figure out how to open the cupboard himself and swallow bleach (or anything else).

Make sure you print at a minimum infill of 70% for the hook. Go for 100% if your toddler works out.
20% should be sufficient for the clasp.

Note: The picture with the brown background shows an older version that doesn't include the little protruding nubs used for stopping the clasp and holding it in place.

constraint.title: Cupboard Knob
constraint.summary:
Just a little knob to help you open the doors, drawers and whatever else you need.
The known stick out about an inch or so, and just under an inch wide. They are a simple design that can be modified quickly should you have the need or the Solid Works software.
UPDATE!!!! 11/10.2013
So I nboticed that on good printers the hole comes out oversized for M4. On my Ultimaker it was just right for self taping. I adjusted the hole to the M4 tap drill size so All you would need to do is tap the hole and way you go.

A childproofing lock to make it very easy to cleanly and securely lock a pair of cabinet doors that open away from each other. This only works if both cabinets have knobs with cylindrical posts/spindles. Look at the pictures and it'll become more clear what's going on. Sorry, but this solution is not for every cabinet in the kitchen or bathroom--it's only specifically for those settings where two doors open opposite each other.

You'll need the diameter of the two spindles on the knobs and the distance between centers on the knobs as installed on the cabinets (measure with the doors closed). The demo stl is provided only for illustration purposes: you'll want to use your own numbers to measure your knobs and your doors to customize the stl for your cabinets. The rest of the parameters in the customizer can be left to defaults to start. Click "open in customizer" above and you'll get a chance to input your parameters and print your custom-fit cabinet lock.

The main reason I invented this is because the ones you can buy in the store are ugly and awkward! I really appreciate feedback on whether this works for you. Please take pictures and post if you get it working! Here's a search for [other products](https://www.amazon.com/gp/search?ie=UTF8&tag=wrenwooddesig-20&linkCode=ur2&linkId=38b0eff887bc770080a33ddd596cce2c&camp=1789&creative=9325&index=aps&keywords=childproof lock) that I considered before deciding that I really wanted to make my own design.

I prefer to print in PLA because if you want to easily adjust the tightness of the lock you just run the elbow under hot water for a minute and bend it a bit tighter or a bit looser. I'm sure you can print it in whatever you want, though. And the parameters in the OpenSCAD file also help you tune it for how tight you want the lock to be / how easy you want it to be to release and re-engage.

I originally designed this one day after my daughter complained that she was unable to open a Jar. I had remembered the Universal Bottle Opener by In3Designs (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3057772) and decided to do something similar.

This requires a flexible type filament (i.e. TPE/TPU) as an insert in order to grip the smooth metal lid.

actuation-operation.title: Jar opener - any size
actuation-operation.summary:
I designed this to make it easier to open Jars that are, well... hard to open. The model fits onto any 220x220 buildplate. I would have made it with four different sizes but then most of you would not be able to print it

There's only two files you need to print:

opener.stl: Should be printed in PLA or in PETG if you want it to last longer. Also make sure you print it with at least 2.0mm wall thickness and at least 35% infill.

TPU part.stl: Should be printed in TPU and also at least 1.6mm wall thickness.

As for the assembly, just glue the two pieces together with whatever you have lying around (I used hot glue), let it dry and you're ready to go.

Edit 08/06/2021 I have added a version where the two pieces are combined for anyone who doesn't have TPU. You can find it in the thing files section under "Opener - one piece.stl". If you're printing this version, you might want to glue a rubber band or something else on for better grip.

actuation-operation.title: Bottle Opener (without metal)
actuation-operation.summary:
This design is a prototype of a purely printed bottle opener design, which means you don't need to add a coin or other metal parts for stability. It's designed to require minimum force and has maximum stability at the critical point (where the cap is lifted).

My printed prototype withstood about 15 bottles of my favorite German beer until it broke. So the current version can only be seen as an "emergency" bottle opener but nothing which lasts long.

An optimization to this as well as an alternative design (also without metal) is under development.

Please read print instructions for good results!

The model is designed in Blender with bezier spline curves, the Blender source file is also available for download.

Makers Making Change is an initiative of the Neil Squire Society, a Canadian non-profit that helps people with disabilities.

We are committed to creating a network of volunteer makers who support people with disabilities in their communities through 3D printing assistive devices. Check out our library of free, open-source assistive technologies with parts and build instructions.

As someone with a mild disability opening bottles can be a little difficult, especially to break those seals. This thing is a 5th generation prototype suitable to release for others to use. Its large and one side has a grip hole for bottle tops around 30mm diameter and the other for 40mm. For me this covers every drink bottle I get, water, softdrink, milks, fruit juices. The inner grips angle inward so slip over and down onto most bottle tops easily for grip regardless of the texture on the bottletop lids. The outer shape is large and overal slightly oval shaped so it provides a good comfortable shape to get a grip on for easy turning. I printed with hard PLA and its great, flexible filaments may offer more grip and comfort. The PLA has stood up to heavy duty dishwasher action so should be safe for you. There is a hole through the middle too if you want to hang it on a hook or if a lid gets stuck in the grip you can poke it out from the otherside with your finger.

Very handy for anyone with hand/grip difficulties such as arthritis or stroke sufferers. Feedback welcome for further improvements.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/kxuTFJf1jyx

Support permettant de stabiliser une bouteille de type "Perrier" en format 1 Litre : cette aide technique évite que la bouteille ne bascule lorsque l'on boit. Ce système est particulièrement pratique pour des personnes alitées qui boivent à l'aide d'une longue paille. Bottle support

This support improves the stability of a Perrier bottle (1L) : this assistive device prevents the bottle from falling down when someone is drinking. This system is especially useful for people confined to bed who drink with a long straw. A nonskid material fixed under the support is strongly recommended in order to avoid the bottle from slipping.

Designed with the help of occupational therapists, at the RehabLab. More information on this website.

actuation-operation.title: Pop-top Can and Bottle Opener
actuation-operation.summary:
Individuals with limited dexterity due either to problems with muscle control or to joint pain can have difficulty opening pop-top cans and opening small bottles.  This assistive device makes it easier to accomplish both tasks.

The device is comprised of two parts:

1) The pop-top can opener has a wedge at one end, a recessed slot to grasp the pop-top, and a rounded bottom to provide leverage to tear off the can top.  It should be printed in a hard plastic like PLA, ABS, or PETG.

2)The bottle opener is mounted inside the larger opening of the pop-top can opener.  It is designed to grip the sides of a bottle top and should be printed out of a flexible plastic like TPU (e.g., Ninjaflex, Polyflex).  If you are unable or reluctant to print with flexible filaments, you can use the pop-top opener without inserting this part.

For more information about assembling and using this device, go to:
https://wp.me/P9evBA-fw

actuation-operation.title: Suitable can opener 01 / Ouvre boite adapté 01
actuation-operation.summary:
Easy Can Opener Extension - Assistive Device
Note: Compatible with Swing-A-Way can openers only

This Can Opener Extension is a snap-fit can opener extension aid for Swing-A-Way can openers. A 75mm extension arm paired with ergonomic knob options, connected by a single 60002RS sealed bearing, allow use of the opener with much less effort. The Can Opener Extension has a snap-fit mount, making it easy to attach and remove for cleaning and storage.

Hardware

  1. M3x6 Socket Head Cap Screws QTY: 2
  2. M3 Nut QTY: 2
  3. 60002RS Sealed Bearings or Equivalent

Assembly Instructions

  1. Installing Bearing

    • Press fit (#3) 60002RS bearing fully into knob
    • Press fit knob/bearing assembly onto spindle of Extension Arm.stl
      Note: Depending on your printers tolerance, you will need to add a non-expanding
      adhesive around spindle to secure the bearing. If you must use this take necessary
      precautions and DO NOT use until adhesives have fully set.

  2. Attach Mount

    • Take Open Mount v2.stl and use one of the M3x6 screws to press/pull in both M3 nuts.
    • Place the pre-assembled Extension Arm.stl into position on Open Mount v2.stl, with the
      arrow facing towards the knob, and fasten down with the 2 M3x6 socket head cap
      screws.
  3. Install Can Opener Extension
    • Snap in the Swing-A-Way knob into Open Mount v2.stl one side at a time starting with
      the side marked with the arrow.
    • While securely holding the arrow marked side of the mount, firmly press the extension
      knob until the assembly snaps into place.

actuation-operation.summary:
Description

This is a pop can opener… more specifically though it’s an incredibly simple, easy to print, and inexpensive lever extension for opening up pop cans with ease. simply slip the lever into place on the tab of a pop can and pull the lever back. Voilà the pop can is open with barely any force required!

Summary

This project started out as a gift for my mother and was a complete success. It has a long way to go, though. While this pop can opener works great and doesn't need a whole lot more tweaking, it's only the beginning. I want this design to inspire new similar designs with a focus on simplicity, inexpensiveness, and ease of use. There's no moving parts, no unnecessary fanciness (although early versions of the design had both of these), it's a simple solution that just works. I plan on continuing to come up with similar designs and I hope everyone who sees this can be inspired to pursue a similar line of thought when coming up with tools for those with arthritis/prosthetics.

Video

Ouvre boite adapté 02 de voyage

Ce système a été conçu pour des personnes manquant de force ou ne pouvant utiliser qu’une seule main (personnes âgées, hémiplégiques, amputés…)

Loïc LB - Ergothérapeute - ALTY-LAB / REHAB-LAB Plérin (22) France

The set is intended for all sizes and forms of preserves.

actuation-operation.title: Suitable travel can opener / Ouvre boite adapté de voyage
CanHandlePlus
actuation-operation.summary:
The revised CanHandle is a bit more stylish than the original and adds a brush holder. The handle gets printed on its side and the brush holder on its back. Neither requires support. Be advised that the tolerances are quite tight and mounting the handle on the can and the brush holder on the handle will require some persuasion. The handle mounts by hooking the outboard barb on the inside rim of the can and then with heavy pressure rotating the inboard barb over the outside rim until it snaps into place. Next the bottom of the handle is attached to the lower rim by pushing downward and inward simultaneously. It is recommended that you install and remove the brush holder a few times to get things loosened up a bit (beware of elephant's foot) and then install the handle without the brush holder, installing the brush holder last. The brush holder is designed for a brush with a 10mm ferrule. You can adjust the gap to be larger or smaller using a hair dryer/heat gun.

If you are installing this on a can which is full of paint.... good luck. I'm betting you'll have a mess on your hands. It is recommended that you empty the can before installation and refill it once CanHandlePlus is successfully installed. Removing the CanHandlePlus is quite a bit easier and it should be possible, with some care, to remove it from a partially filled can.

By the way, keep your rim trim and free from paint with the QT_RimTrim (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5932062)

Here's a short video demonstrating installation:https://www.youtube.com/shorts/HCgX8A0RXlA

This design is for a U.S. quart paint can. I'm not sure if all paint cans are identical so here are the dimensions of the can I used: 108mm outside diameter, 80mm inside diameter, 14mm rim width, 123mm high rim to rim. I have included the Fusion 360 files if you need to make adjustments.

actuation-operation.title: Liquid soap/hand sanitizer dispenser for single hand/forearm use.
actuation-operation.summary:
[8/6/20 V2 hinge pin uploaded - now contoured and sized to sit flush against the main body for a much nicer look.

I did design a variant that had a much less bulky body, but it ended up using practically the same amount of filament due to the amount of support material needed].

A simple application of a lever to make pushing the pump easier.

Perfect to folk with weaker wrists, arthritis, larger tools etc.

Functioning base designed for a bottle with a 27mm diameter neck, and a 30mm diameter lid. You may need to shave the inner ring a little to adjust to fit perfectly (it's a tight fit!)

Works best if the bottle has quite a wide base to prevent it from toppling. Results may vary with different bottle shapes/sizes!

The design should scale up without an issue but may need a little rework if scaling down, due to clearance tolerances being designed for this sized print.

Included is also a base without a hole in the bottom. Will accommodate any diameter lid up to 30mm - all you need to do is add a hole in the centre of the recess to accommodate the diameter of bottleneck you need.

PLEASE POST YOUR MAKES/REMIXES!

Please respect the CC licence and share with the same settings - assistive aids should be free and open-source!

Prints without supports, however, you may want to enable supports just to help out the curve around the hinge area get started.

The hand sanitizer provided in the lifts at my apartment building was useful but required users to press on the top.

The design is provided as a reference for a hands-free sanitizer dispenser. Feel free to make your own versions. I have also included some images of the dimensions of the bottle and lift handle.

A toothpick was used in the hinge to join the clamp to the main body.

The top piece can be easily slipped on and off the spout for refills.

The roller piece at the bottom helps lift the pipe away from the wall.

actuation-operation.title: 'Cheat Sticks' - The easy way to keep your Chop Sticks under control!
actuation-operation.summary:
'Cheat Sticks' is a small Chop Stick alignment helper. Positioned correctly this subtle little helper maintains the distance between the Chop Sticks at the control / pivot point as well as minimizes side movement without affecting rotational movement (...required to grab food)

Many people struggle with using Chop Sticks, particularly if you don't use them often to get in practice, so this handy little slide on alignment helper could be just what you need. "Cheat Sticks have been designed to let you use Chop Sticks as they are meant to be used (i.e. The lower Chop Stick stays still and the top Chop Stick rotates up and down around a pivot point at the centre of your thumb). 'Once located correctly Cheat Sticks' minimises the sideways movement of your Chop Sticks... keeping them under control.

Just slide 'Cheat Sticks' onto your regular pair of Chop Sticks to the point where you want your thumb located (approx. 2/3 of the length up from the tips). Hold the Chop Sticks in the correct way and your 'Cheat Sticks' will help keep them aligned as you use them.

Most Chop Stick Helpers I've seen change the way Chop Sticks work because they either make them springy when moved from the neutral point or they link them at the top so turn them into giant tweezers. 'Cheat Sticks' are different in that they let you move your Chop Sticks in the correct way without any springy effect. They just help keep your Chop Sticks aligned.

Tips for use:

As Chop Stickers vary in size make sure you position your 'Cheat Sticks' at the point they still allow free rotation but minimize side movement (i.e. Locating 'Cheat Sticks' too far down the taper of the Chop Sticks will reduce their effectiveness as they Chop Sticks will be have increased potential to move sideways).

If your Chop Sticks are very thick or thin you can adjust the Z-scale prior to printing to ensure a snug fit can be achieved to minimize sideways movement of the Chop Sticks. The standard file has been developed to suit most 'common' size Chop Sticks (6.75 to 7.25mm at the wide end).

Rest your thumb on 'Cheat Sticks' to hold it in place but also try and keep the tip of your thumb so it can touch the top (moving) Chop Stick. This can further help with control.

actuation-operation.title: Killing the lights
actuation-operation.summary:
Want to kill the lights? Simply slide this on your light switch and shoot with your nerf gun. Print at somewhat high infill or it won't last very long.

As requested i made another design that can turn the lights on and off. this is for the best marksmen. A 3mm set screw slot has been added so that the target is less likely to fall of the switch.

I have two light switches in my house that are hard to reach because they are behind furniture. The light switches in my house are the flat "Decora" style, so I could not use @Bingbingaling's extender for the "toggle" style. So I designed a new thing that works for me.

This is a single piece print that has 2 captive moving parts. There is 0.2 mm of gap so that the sliding parts will not escape the 45 degree walled slot which contains them. My printer has a 150mm square bed and this design will just fit within that square when angled 45 degrees.

see it here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n_84355Am7U

You'll need two 3/4" long flathead 6-32 screws to mount this.

If you have a larger print bed you may want to remix this and extend the handle. If you mount a longer one upside down then you can use it for young kids to reach the switch.

Here's the source OpenSCAD file:
https://github.com/danmarshall/openscad-decora-switch-extension

You can get the source OpenSCAD for just the sliding bolt component on my GitHub: https://github.com/danmarshall/openscad-sliding-bolt

constraint.summary:
Imagine a trigger guard on a gun, but for a light switch. This guard prevents the switch from being accidentally flipped, and also acts to discourage flipping the switch in general.

In my case, I have a switch in my apartment which turns off the outlet that my cable modem and router are plugged into. This guard allows me to flip the switch when I need to (to reset the router/modem when they're misbehaving), while making it much less likely that someone will inadvertently kill my internet connection when trying to find the switch for the lights.

This is an FDM s̶l̶a̶ friendly remix of someone elses design. It should fit standard North American light switch covers. Prints in 2 pieces with supports as needed for the cover.
Update: Brain slip, i originally posted this as SLA Friendly, It probably is, but its designed to be FDM Friendly, not SLA.

General Safety Warning - You are responsible for your own actions. If you don't know what you are doing then don't try it.

To assemble:
1: Remove the screws from the existing cover plate and place the printed base over top, re-using the screws to attach it to the switch cover plate.

2: Hold the cover with the cross bar toward the loops on the base ~45degrees open.
You should see the flats on the cross bar align with the slots in the loops.

3: Moving the cover plate at a slight angle, slide one side of the cross bar into the matching loop of the base plate. Then align the flat on the bar with the slot in the other loop and firmly push. Be careful, especially if you have poor layer adhesion as the loop may break and require a reprint.

4: The cover should now be captive between the rings, but swing-able on the hinge. The design has a slight latching action when the cover is lifted and it should hold itself open if you wish. This wasn't an intentional feature but its a happy accident.

constraint.title: Missile Light Switch Cover
constraint.summary:
Do you want a way to make sure light switches are in the "off" position?
Do you want your room to look like a missile command room?
Do you want to accidentally avoid turning on a switch?

If any of these are true (or even if they aren't), you can also print a cover for your standard US wall light toggle switch!

(Couldn't get the other models I found to work smoothly, so designed my own from scratch.)

The pieces are "press fit" (carefully) and require no additional hardware. For the best success, align one side into the hole, and then press in the other side from "the top" (aka the tip/center of the curve) -- this seems like the easiest/safest place.

[2022-02-02] Added "SmallerNubs" version; made the nubs slightly smaller to maybe allow them to slot in easier.

[2022-02-02] Added "PiP_untested" version; realigned the model (and increased the gap between the top of cover and the base) to allow for printing-in-place. Print with plate support!

[2022-02-02] Added "Lock" version; removes the doogit that switches the switch off, so you can have a "allow on" cover.

Guard for common household light switch, providing default position and guarding against accidental movement out of default position. Deliberately makes movement from default position difficult, but still possible when desired using finger tip. Movement back to default position is very easy.

Inspired by thing:1703339, but designed from scratch with rounded ends, beveled edges, and more protection in the default position.

Sketchup design file included.

EDIT 5-11-2017: Per request, I uploaded an STL with the horizontal dimension of the opening enlarged by 1.3mm (0.05in). The opening on the standard version is 9.4mm (0.37in), and on the version suffixed with "_wide" it is 10.7mm (0.42in). The _wide version may be useful if your switch is wider, or your printer is over-extruding a bit.

constraint.title: Light Switch Lock
constraint.summary:
4/21/16
For citizen named "lowlight". Added a slight modification to the design. This will make it harder for the switch to accidently be turned off by adding support against the switch arm.

I have a problem with people turning off light switches that for most part need to stay in the on position. If you have a boiler switch or front door light that you like to keep on, this device will help remind your busy fingered friends that this switch is not to be touched. Although the design allows you to over-ride the on position by moving the arm out of the way and still turn off the switch.

You need to print with support there is a detail the has a cut away to clear the switch area.

I also included the CREO .pk2

constraint.title: Child Light Switch Extender
constraint.summary:
My 4yr old was unable to reach the bathroom light easily and would always scream for help. Now he can reach it on his own.

You will also need:

1 chop stick
2 small screws (I cut mine even shorter so that it didn't screw through the chop stick into the light switch)

You may not need the cap for the top of the chop stick. My chop stick had the squared off top that worked fine as is. The chop stick I also used was more oval. You may need to modify if your chop stick is round.

Enjoy!

NEWEST UPDATE
Added even more designs, including:
Arrow
Bed(s)
Car
Chair
Dining
Door

Water droplet

UPDATE
Just added a new icon for a sink disposal...
AND
center aligned versions of the lightbulb and outlet icons so they are centered with the rest!

Do you turn off the power to the TV plug when your just trying to turn on a light? Are you embarrassed when your guest go through the gauntlet of switches in the guest room to figure out which one will allow them to see? Are you tired of fumbling for the fan switch on a hot summer night only to blind your partner by hitting the wrong switch and almost ending your relationship?

I have tried stickers and labels, but they always looked dumpy.

I designed these little identifiers that use the existing screws on a switchplate for a simple, clean and fun solution. Low profile and easy to install. Should fit most standard switchplate screws. Print in any color you like! (as long as you have that color filament...)

I can add more styles if people find a need for them.

If you find these helpful and print yourself some, I always appreciate tips and shares of my design!

Check out my YouTube channel for more content of things I have made: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UClcXhXUQD8r3n7QZsWlaj4A

actuation-operation.title: Decora light switch extension
actuation-operation.summary:
I have two light switches in my house that are hard to reach because they are behind furniture. The light switches in my house are the flat "Decora" style, so I could not use @Bingbingaling's extender for the "toggle" style. So I designed a new thing that works for me.

This is a single piece print that has 2 captive moving parts. There is 0.2 mm of gap so that the sliding parts will not escape the 45 degree walled slot which contains them. My printer has a 150mm square bed and this design will just fit within that square when angled 45 degrees.

see it here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n_84355Am7U

You'll need two 3/4" long flathead 6-32 screws to mount this.

If you have a larger print bed you may want to remix this and extend the handle. If you mount a longer one upside down then you can use it for young kids to reach the switch.

Here's the source OpenSCAD file:
https://github.com/danmarshall/openscad-decora-switch-extension

You can get the source OpenSCAD for just the sliding bolt component on my GitHub: https://github.com/danmarshall/openscad-sliding-bolt
