constraint.title: Light Switch Guard
constraint.summary:
Guard for common household light switch, providing default position and guarding against accidental movement out of default position. Deliberately makes movement from default position difficult, but still possible when desired using finger tip. Movement back to default position is very easy.

Inspired by thing:1703339, but designed from scratch with rounded ends, beveled edges, and more protection in the default position.

Sketchup design file included.

EDIT 5-11-2017: Per request, I uploaded an STL with the horizontal dimension of the opening enlarged by 1.3mm (0.05in). The opening on the standard version is 9.4mm (0.37in), and on the version suffixed with "_wide" it is 10.7mm (0.42in). The _wide version may be useful if your switch is wider, or your printer is over-extruding a bit.

constraint.title: Light Switch Lock
constraint.summary:
4/21/16
For citizen named "lowlight". Added a slight modification to the design. This will make it harder for the switch to accidently be turned off by adding support against the switch arm.

I have a problem with people turning off light switches that for most part need to stay in the on position. If you have a boiler switch or front door light that you like to keep on, this device will help remind your busy fingered friends that this switch is not to be touched. Although the design allows you to over-ride the on position by moving the arm out of the way and still turn off the switch.

You need to print with support there is a detail the has a cut away to clear the switch area.

I also included the CREO .pk2

constraint.title: Child Light Switch Extender
constraint.summary:
My 4yr old was unable to reach the bathroom light easily and would always scream for help. Now he can reach it on his own.

You will also need:

1 chop stick
2 small screws (I cut mine even shorter so that it didn't screw through the chop stick into the light switch)

You may not need the cap for the top of the chop stick. My chop stick had the squared off top that worked fine as is. The chop stick I also used was more oval. You may need to modify if your chop stick is round.

Enjoy!

indication-visual.title: Switchplate Identifiers
indication-visual.summary:
NEWEST UPDATE
Added even more designs, including:
Arrow
Bed(s)
Car
Chair
Dining
Door
Stairs
Water droplet

UPDATE
Just added a new icon for a sink disposal...
AND
center aligned versions of the lightbulb and outlet icons so they are centered with the rest!

Do you turn off the power to the TV plug when your just trying to turn on a light? Are you embarrassed when your guest go through the gauntlet of switches in the guest room to figure out which one will allow them to see? Are you tired of fumbling for the fan switch on a hot summer night only to blind your partner by hitting the wrong switch and almost ending your relationship?

I have tried stickers and labels, but they always looked dumpy.

I designed these little identifiers that use the existing screws on a switchplate for a simple, clean and fun solution. Low profile and easy to install. Should fit most standard switchplate screws. Print in any color you like! (as long as you have that color filament...)

I can add more styles if people find a need for them.

If you find these helpful and print yourself some, I always appreciate tips and shares of my design!

Check out my YouTube channel for more content of things I have made: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UClcXhXUQD8r3n7QZsWlaj4A

indication-visual.title: Light Switch Cover
indication-visual.summary:
This is a light switch cover designed to protect a switch from being accidentally turned on or off. It is designed to replace the stock light-switch cover, and should fit on all standard switches. This cover is designed to go on the wall horizontally, "OFF" will be upsidedown if you put it vertically. If you want a vertically friendly version just comment below and i'll spin a second model for you.

I made a couple changes to the model after I first printed it. 1) I made the opening for the switch bigger just to make sure it fits all switches, my print required just a little sanding to fit. 2) I increased the distance between letters just a tiny bit for appearance sake.

Note: current pictures are of revision one. I'll get pictures of revision 3 up when its done printing.

Revisions:

October 28th: I Just uploaded revision 2. The first addition did not sit flush against the wall due to the switch guts, this one has a recessed bottom to prevent that. You will need to print it with supports now, and i would recommend a brim to help with warping.

November 18th: Uploaded revision 3. I made the primary box a little deeper, hopefully letting it sit against the surface a little better. More importantly increased the size and length of the ribs, so that the entire switch was covered.

constraint.title: German Power Outlet Dust Cover
constraint.summary:
A simple dust protector for a German Schuko power outlet. Since the thing is hold in place by the springy ground contacts print precision isn't all that important. 0.2 layer height and no supports should work fine.

This thing is not meant as a child safety device and can relatively easily be removed with just fingers.

Update (2021-06-16): Add FreeCad version and STEP file.

I bought a safety outlet cover from Toys r us a few years back, and now I needed to get more and I could not find in any of the stores near by. So I decided to make one.

I also uploaded the Sketchup file if you want to customise it for your needs.

constraint.title: Dust Cover for Schuko Power Outlet
constraint.summary:
I remixed the power outlet dust cover by grumbel, because I want to swap it more often in and out.

I use it in the kitchen near the hot plate, where tomato sauce may be splashed or likewise. :)

Therefore the cover is a little bit thicker with some cut outs to pull it out more easily. I also adjusted the width between the springs to make it a little bit more loose.

Update 2020-12-23

I made two additional version: Half and Small in order to cover the hole left in the Schuko outlet, when an Euro-Plug (Type C) is inserted.

There is also childproof version with less width between the earth-springs and without the grips. (basically back to the design idea by grumble ...)
I don't garantee your child is not able to pull the cover out. Give it a try!

If you like the design a coffee would be great.

Robust power strip mount.

Advantages:

  • Firm clamping mechanism - no wiggling.
  • Mount with screws or cable ties on walls, panels, etc..
  • Robust design for heavy use (e.g. in a workshop)

Designs:

  • variable number of outlets: bracket_single.stl
  • 3-outlet power strip: bracket_triple.stl (Note: the separation distance between the outlets is 4mm)

Compatible power strips: tested for EU plug power strips only, e.g. Ikea Koppla and equivalent cheap power strips from a hardware store.

  • width: max. 55mm
  • height: 39-45mm

If you need this mount for a different size of power strips, please feel free to contact me! I am happy to add e.g. US and UK versions.

Additional Material needed:

  • Wood Screws diameter 4-4.5mm, length 35-45mm

Changelog:
2020_02_03: Added versions without flange.

actuation-operation.title: Bag Holder - Shopping Handle
actuation-operation.summary:
This is a simple thing to help you carry your bags. It doesent hurt your finger, and is really elegant to use.. (=])

Use 10% of infill or more. If you like being the "Hulk", print with 70% and you will carry the World.

Handle for carrying one or more shopping bags. The slim version is slightly narrower for smaller hands and the wide slot version is designed for bags with slightly thicker handles. You may want to adjust the scale before printing.

actuation-operation.title: Assistive Technology - Bag Holder
actuation-operation.summary:
This is my iteration of the great design by ivan_gee.

Things I've changed:

  • I added a fillet at the wrist part, as well as a little rounded cut-out to better fit the natural form of your wrist.

  • There is a little more space to get the wrist inside, since I found the original model to be a tad too narrow.

  • The middle part is a little longer, so that the hand can be relaxed and the person using it doesn't have to make a fist while carrying.

  • All in all I rounded over a lot of things and tried to give the whole design a little more organic feel.

If you want to see what else I do, you can check out my YouTube Channel:
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCqaNAu9dOwhEgRsv0PmXHoA

My cousin Juan Luis, from Pamplona (Spain), can't use his left arm and I have seen him so many times opening metal zippers, that I decided to do something about it. With EasyZipper you can use your teeth or some other means, to open your zippers.
This EasyZipper is a generic design that will let you fit most of standard zippers. Just use a cable tie and you are done. I hope it will be useful for many people.
You can watch some easy instructions in this video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uqsHwKfUz3w

Mi primo Juan Luis, de Pamplona (España), no puede usar su brazo izquierdo y le he visto muchas veces abrir cremalleras metálicas, que decidí hacer algo al respecto. Con EasyZipper puedes usar tus dientes u otros medios, para abrir cremalleras.
Este EasyZypper es un diseño genérico que te permitirá adaptarlo a la mayoría de cremalleras. Simplemente usa una brida para fijarlo y ya está. En el video tienes algunas instrucciones sencillas.

actuation-operation.summary:
Ball Stylus can be customized for ball size, stylus length, and surface smoothness.

For more information on assistive technology, visit http://www.rehabengineer.com, or our agency at http://rehab.alabama.gov/ .

Anse pour téléphone portable

Cette aide technique est une bague reliée à une plaquette qui viendra se scratcher ou se coller sur le téléphone pour que le patient puisse le tenir plus facilement.

Créée au RehabLab du CMRRF de Kerpape (Bretagne, France), avec l'aide d'ergothérapeutes.
Plus d'informations sur le site.

Phone ring

This assistive device,created at the CMRRF de Kerpape (France), is a phone ring which allows a better phone maintaining.

Designed with the help of occupational therapists, at the RehabLab. More information on this website.

constraint.title: LiftPod - Multipurpose Foldable Stand
constraint.summary:
This is a multipurpose stand to mount cameras, phones, Nintendo Switch, or tablets.

The clamp is compatible with common Arca-Swiss style camera tripod plate.

It's fully printed.

Assembly video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TnSc7jnhCS0

If you prefer the 4-fold set, the easy lock edition is a better choice: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4625988

If you find this design helpful, consider to support my work. Thanks in advance.

Download object holders such as phone clamp, camera plate, tablet holders from here

Download the vice clamp from here

Parts for optional metal M5x25 bolts and nuts here

Rotary base here

Elongated arms or odd arm spacer here

Swivel joint arm here

There are several options of printing the washers for optimised folding experience.

  • Standard is friction washer printed with hard filament. It's the smoothest to operate but can't hold heavy objects.
  • It can also be printed with flexible filament for more friction, but a bit noisy to operate.
  • If you are using it with heavy camera or extra long arms, use the locking washer which has teeth to prevent falling, especially for the base joints. The teeth allow 22.5 degree rotation segments.

All objects are orientated properly. The bolts are printed horizontally.

Tighten the knobs carefully. TWO knobs are necessary for each bolt to lock properly, to prevent unscrewing when folding the arms. It's important that the two knobs are tight between each other, and the compression between the knob and arm is less.

Only one knob is needed to use with locking washer.

Print "Base feet" with FLEXIBLE material for friction.

Print settings:

  • 0.2mm layer height
  • No support
  • 4 Wall lines
  • At least 35% infill

UPDATE HISTORY:

  • 2020-11-07 - Arm First v2: Teeth groove made slightly deeper.
  • 2020-10-30 - Clamp Frame v2 update: tray made slightly shallower so objects stay still when unclamping.
  • 2020-10-19 - Clamp bolt v2 update. Less likely to strip.
  • 2020-10-18 - Bolt and bar updated. Removed unnecessary chamfer which might cause the hex to strip within the socket and added more touching edges.
  • 2020-10-08 - Added extension arm for more folds. Adjusted locking teeth orientation to remove confusion. New knob for locking washer. Made teeth groove on arms slightly deeper. More tolerance on bar thread.

*Make sure to setup the folding strength to a sufficient level. Use locking washer if necessary. I'm not responsible for potential damage to your devices.

constraint.title: Phone Stand
constraint.summary:
Made it for my iPhone 6, but i guess it will fit other models as well. Cable goes through the hole and you're good to go. Will upload pictures when i've printed it, so a simple render is all you get to see for now.

NOTE: I have made this for my own use/preference, so I really don't care if it's not suitable for your specified phone etc.. Please dont nag. If you want to modify, feel free!

Added the work file, so you can modify it for your own phone.

-Rotate it so it lays 'sideways', then add supports and you're good to go.

Enjoy!

**Update (6/23/2018): I'm sharing this Fusion 360 model(I hope I did it right): https://a360.co/2KgA3Z9

I'm sorry to anyone who has tried to contact me. I've been busy with a full-time job plus engineering classes. Every time I log in, I see that I have infinity notifications waiting for me to address them.

But, I finally took the time to figure out how to share the model so you can make changes or fix the model in any way you want.

I'm glad so many people have gotten use out of my design.

**Update (7/24/2017): Important notes in the print settings.

I've been debating mounting a TV on the ceiling above my bed. The only reason I haven't done it is because of a fear of being crushed by a falling TV while I'm sleeping.

This design allows me to watch Youtube, Netflix, or other streaming video while I'm falling asleep.

Non-Printed Parts:
Adhesive Metal Plate for Magnetic Phone Mounts
4-Pack Enkay 4480-C Magnets
4x Screws that fit in a 5 mm hole with a head diameter no larger than 7.9 mm
4x Wall Anchors for those screws
Electrical Tape

If I had to guess on the screw size based on the charts I found online, I would say it's a #10 screw, but I designed the wall mount around some unlabeled screws and anchors I had lying around.

indication-tactile.title: 11" HP Chromebook Keyguard
indication-tactile.summary:
This is a keyguard I created for people with tremors or CP. It is held on to the Chromebook with double sided tape. The keyguard's height is the same as the keys on this particular HP Chromebook allowing for the person to close the lid without breaking the LCD panel. I made the Tinkercad design (Chromebook Keyguard) public on the Tinkercad site in case someone needs to adjust particular keys.

I connected the two halves using a 3d pen with the same filament.

indication-tactile.title: Carcasa para Mac Book Pro (Mac Book Pro Keyguard)
indication-tactile.summary:
Español:
Esta pieza independiza cada una de las teclas del ordenador dejándolas encerradas, así se podrá apoyar la mano sobre el teclado sin activar ninguna tecla, ayudando a evitar pulsaciones equivocadas o la activación de varias teclas a la vez.

Facilita la actividad a aquellas personas que necesitan apoyo de la mano para mejorar la precisión de sus movimientos al teclear.

English:
This technical aid separates each of the computer keys leaving them independent, so you can rest your hand on the keyboard without activating any key, helping to avoid wrong keystrokes or the activation of several keys at the same time.

It facilitates the activity to those people who need support for his/her hands to improve the precision of their movements when typing.

actuation-operation.summary:
All too often toast can be difficult to remove from a toaster (even with a lift mechanism to raise the height of the toast) dues to the height/shape of the bread toasted. To get the toast out people have been known to try all sorts of things that can result in burns or, even worse, an electric shock.

You can buy wooden tongs to do a similar thing but they go down the sides of the toast so can get very close to or damage the toaster elements. Because they are made of wood, over time they can also get burnt from the hot metal surfaces, albeit better than your fingers getting burnt. And, they are quite expensive for what they are,

The design incorporates a rotating joint so the arms can swing in/out to suit the width of the piece of toast. This could have been made to spring open, so force required to narrow them, but that meant additional pressure would be required to securely grab the toast not to mention a loss of feel. The Toast Extractor is not springy so it needs very little pressure to pinch onto the toast and lift it out.

This is a one piece print with independently moving parts. No support required. With a well set up / accurate machine you should only have to give the joint a gentle 'wiggle' after printing for it to come free and start rotating easily.

Refer to images and print instructions for more information.

Note: If you like this check out all my other designs!

The 'Toast Extractor' is your solution...

Rather than being inserted into the toaster between the toast and elements the 'Toast Extractor' grabs the sides of the toast. The arms of the 'Toast Extractor' don't go into the element area or touch the metal parts at all. They just let you grab the toast... think of them as finger extensions.

actuation-operation.title: Ring Writer/Painter etc... Clip Assistant Device
actuation-operation.summary:
Ring Writer/Painter etc... Clip assist those that suffer from gripping problems, arthritis, dexterity limitations or restricted mobility and consist of two connected rings.

Ring Writer/Painter etc... Clip Assistant Device is set up to immediately position the writing aid at the correct angle ( 35 degrees to maintain perfect pozicion to write according to the current study ) for proper use. The user is not required to use much or any gripping at all.

The bigger ring is for the user's finger and the smaller ring is for the writing utensil. This assisted writing tool works with pens, pencils, crayons, paint brushes, and a variety of other items. Ring Writer/Painter is designed to align itself correctly for the user once it is slipped on their finger.

Ring Writer/Painter etc... Clip Design Specifications:

• Large size dimensions: 2.50cm

Printing time 30 min +/- with 100% infill.

This is designed to fit a writing utensil, such as a crayon or writing pen. The ball is 50mm. The hole in the middle is 9mm. Utensil is held in place by a two each of 1/4-20 set screws. The set screw holes will need to have the threads cut buy a 1/4-20 tap available at any hardware store. Instead of a 1/4-20 setscrew, a 6mm-1 could be substituted.

actuation-operation.title: [K] Aide maintien crayon (Pen holder)
actuation-operation.summary:
English translation further down.

Aide au maintien d'un crayon

Cette aide technique permet à un enfant de maintenir un crayon en serrant le support dans son poing, à l'horizontale. Le pas de vis permet d'inclure tout type de crayon à l'intérieur du support sans risque pour l'enfant.

L'utilisation du plugin Surfaces floues de Cura permet d'avoir un état de surface rugueux en contact avec la main de l'enfant, ce qui permet de mieux maintenir la main sans blesser l'utilisateur.

Créée au RehabLab du CMRRF de Kerpape (Bretagne, France), avec l'aide d'ergothérapeutes.
Plus d'informations sur le site.

Pen holder for children

This Thing is an assistive device created at the CMRRF de Kerpape (France). It aims to help children who cannot hold a pen between their fingers. Children can use this device to draw, holding the device in their palm as shown in the picture above.

Every type of pen can be inserted into this technical aid thanks to a screw thread which hold the pen still.

The Fuzzy Skin Cura plugin can be used to improve the stability of the device without hurting the child.

Designed with the help of occupational therapists, at the RehabLab. More information on this website.

Many people with disabilities such as cerebral palsy (not limited to CP) can grasp with their hand but not rotate at the wrist. This means that they can not draw or write on paper, as the the pen is usually parallel to the paper.

This device is designed to hold a pen or marker vertically while being held itself horizontally. By loosening the thumbscrew, the pen or maker can be switched out at will.

It uses a captive square nut and a thumbscrew to help maintain the pressure on the marker. The openSCAD file can be adjusted for different diameters, finger grip positions, etc.
For people with finger dexterity issues, holding a pen and write can be a challenge. This pen holder fits to a pen and the fingers

actuation-operation.title: Universal Spoon Holder
actuation-operation.summary:
I'm a Occupational therapist.
I modeled this for the people who have some difficulty to manipulate their fingers.
This model will assist to handle your spoon.
Please enjoy your meals and have fun!

For people with finger dexterity issues, holding a spoon or fork can be a challenge. This utensil holder securely straps to a user's hand with velcro and has a universal slot to fit different sized utensils.

This design includes both right and left handed versions. Use 3/4" width velcro for the straps.


Volunteer your 3D printing skills to help people with disabilities in your community!

Makers Making Change is an initiative of the Neil Squire Society, a Canadian non-profit that helps people with disabilities.

We are committed to creating a network of volunteer makers who support people with disabilities in their communities through 3D printing assistive devices. Check out our library of free, open-source assistive technologies with parts and build instructions.

The Andrew Fork is an assistive device for the two-handed task of cutting food with a knife and fork. Young Andrew Forest was unable to comfortably grasp a fork with his right hand, so he used modeling clay to shape a special handle for his fork. His mom baked the assembly in the oven to make it rigid enough for Andrew to use. This seemed like such a good idea that we wondered if Andrew’s invention would be useful for other people with hand differences. So we used Tinkercad to develop the fork handle for 3D Printing.

The design fits a fork available from the Dollar Tree store in a 2-pack for $1. Do not use PLA filament (so that the assembly can be washed in a dishwasher). The STL file allows for the shrinkage in ABS and Nylon. For flexible material like Cheetah or rigid filament that does not shrink, try a version that is scaled to .9 on the x-axis in your slicer. A ziptie can be used to secure the fork in the handle.

If you don’t have a 3D printer, try getting a quote from 3D Hubs or Shapeways or do a google search on 3D printing services with your zipcode.

Feel free to hack or remix the design to make it fit your fork better. You can start with the Tinkercad File. Or do what Andrew and other e-NABLE volunteers are doing and develop some other assistive devices for other tasks. We would love to hear if Andrew’s invention works for other people too.

Go to the Enabling The Future website to join our free and open source community.

Challenge:
What we really need is a design with a simple geometry that will securely capture a wide range of fork sizes and shapes. Consider remixing the Tinkercad design for the 267 Fork Handle and see what you can come up with.

actuation-operation.title: Bowers Assistive Fork
actuation-operation.summary:
This fork holder is designed for people with limited mobility to create a customizable eating utensil. Using this fork holder and handle and some easily obtainable parts such as 1/2" PVC pipe and a rubber band, this assistive device can be used to manipulate a fork while keeping your hands below table level. Unlike other overly complex assistive devices, it requires no screws or power. The handle is designed to support traditional and nontraditional gripping strategies.

I have used and relied on this design daily to eat independently since 2012. It's taken many redesigns to get it just right: to print without support, to be light-weight, and to print on small printers, but I am very satisfied with it. It looks more attractive than other designs I've used made by occupational therapists, and can be fully taken apart to be cleaned. Every fork I've tried has fit well, from plastic to heavy dinnerware. This design alone has made a 3-D printer a must-have device in my house!

Hi, my name is Brian Thornber. I am a 16 year old 11th grade student, interested in becoming a 3D Printing Engineer. I've made an object, to help me improve my skills, and to help other people with every day problems.

Introducing the EasyFork. The EasyFork, is exactly what it sounds like. It's a fork, made for use by people who have trouble gripping onto things, weather heavily disabled, or just mild arthritis, the EasyFork is good for most everything. My inspiration for this was the fact that my grandfather had Parkinson's, and couldn't hold onto his own fork or spoon. With simple full hand grips, it makes it easy to start using the EasyFork, and easy to hold onto it. With a very simple design, it is a very cheap and easy way to help those who have trouble holding onto every day items.

Heres a demo: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nj_Xlt0znMw&feature=youtu.be

actuation-operation.title: Right Angel Utensil Holder
actuation-operation.summary: Remade with the ability to grip a flat/wide-end spoon or fork. Also added 2 slits to add rubber bands for additional grip if required.

Este producto de apoyo consta de una parte principal y una correa de sujeción con la que puede ser combinado.
La parte principal es una base donde colocamos un anillo, donde irá el dedo índice de forma que podrá ejercer la fuerza necesaria para "pinchar" el alimento.
La correa de sujeción nos permite colocar el producto de apoyo en la mano del paciente y así poder simular de la forma más sencilla la actividad de la vida diaria y trabajar para su rehabilitación.

El agarre de los cubiertos es bastante complejo para los pacientes neurológicos ya que requiere de una combinación de movimientos muy finos además de un control motor importante para que no se caiga el alimento, con estos productos de apoyo trabajamos la funcionalidad del miembro superior en una de las tareas más importantes para el ser humano como es la alimentación

Digitally molded a model. Now we are available with flex filament.

If you found this useful, please donate what you think it is worth to my paypal.me. Help cover the time of design.
Thanks, Enjoy!

This is my entry for the Assistive Technology Challenge.

Millions of people are dealing with a verity of issues with their hands from arthritis, injury, or other illness. Such issues can make their silverware impossible to use.

These adaptive handles are designed to help those with dexterity issues use their ordinary household silverware without having to buy expensive sets from a commercial company. These handles will work for anyone with weak grip, no grip (because it slips between your fingers) or thumb amputees.

With a couple rubber bands, you can attach your silverware to the base of this handle. This will let you use your silverware without a strong grip or thumb.

actuation-operation.title: Spoon holder
actuation-operation.summary:
The Andrew Fork is an assistive device for the two-handed task of cutting food with a knife and fork. Young Andrew Forest was unable to comfortably grasp a fork with his right hand, so he used modeling clay to shape a special handle for his fork. His mom baked the assembly in the oven to make it rigid enough for Andrew to use. This seemed like such a good idea that we wondered if Andrew’s invention would be useful for other people with hand differences. So we used Tinkercad to develop the fork handle for 3D Printing.

The design fits a fork available from the Dollar Tree store in a 2-pack for $1. Do not use PLA filament (so that the assembly can be washed in a dishwasher). The STL file allows for the shrinkage in ABS and Nylon. For flexible material like Cheetah or rigid filament that does not shrink, try a version that is scaled to .9 on the x-axis in your slicer. A ziptie can be used to secure the fork in the handle.

If you don’t have a 3D printer, try getting a quote from 3D Hubs or Shapeways or do a google search on 3D printing services with your zipcode.

Feel free to hack or remix the design to make it fit your fork better. You can start with the Tinkercad File. Or do what Andrew and other e-NABLE volunteers are doing and develop some other assistive devices for other tasks. We would love to hear if Andrew’s invention works for other people too.

Go to the Enabling The Future website to join our free and open source community.

Challenge:
What we really need is a design with a simple geometry that will securely capture a wide range of fork sizes and shapes. Consider remixing the Tinkercad design for the 267 Fork Handle and see what you can come up with.

actuation-operation.title: Bowers Assistive Fork
actuation-operation.summary:
This fork holder is designed for people with limited mobility to create a customizable eating utensil. Using this fork holder and handle and some easily obtainable parts such as 1/2" PVC pipe and a rubber band, this assistive device can be used to manipulate a fork while keeping your hands below table level. Unlike other overly complex assistive devices, it requires no screws or power. The handle is designed to support traditional and nontraditional gripping strategies.

I have used and relied on this design daily to eat independently since 2012. It's taken many redesigns to get it just right: to print without support, to be light-weight, and to print on small printers, but I am very satisfied with it. It looks more attractive than other designs I've used made by occupational therapists, and can be fully taken apart to be cleaned. Every fork I've tried has fit well, from plastic to heavy dinnerware. This design alone has made a 3-D printer a must-have device in my house!

actuation-operation.title: EasyFork - Assistive Tech Challenge
actuation-operation.summary:
Hi, my name is Brian Thornber. I am a 16 year old 11th grade student, interested in becoming a 3D Printing Engineer. I've made an object, to help me improve my skills, and to help other people with every day problems.

Introducing the EasyFork. The EasyFork, is exactly what it sounds like. It's a fork, made for use by people who have trouble gripping onto things, weather heavily disabled, or just mild arthritis, the EasyFork is good for most everything. My inspiration for this was the fact that my grandfather had Parkinson's, and couldn't hold onto his own fork or spoon. With simple full hand grips, it makes it easy to start using the EasyFork, and easy to hold onto it. With a very simple design, it is a very cheap and easy way to help those who have trouble holding onto every day items.

Heres a demo: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nj_Xlt0znMw&feature=youtu.be

actuation-operation.title: Fork Holder
actuation-operation.summary:
Este producto de apoyo consta de una parte principal y una correa de sujeción con la que puede ser combinado.
La parte principal es una base donde colocamos un anillo, donde irá el dedo índice de forma que podrá ejercer la fuerza necesaria para "pinchar" el alimento.
La correa de sujeción nos permite colocar el producto de apoyo en la mano del paciente y así poder simular de la forma más sencilla la actividad de la vida diaria y trabajar para su rehabilitación.

El agarre de los cubiertos es bastante complejo para los pacientes neurológicos ya que requiere de una combinación de movimientos muy finos además de un control motor importante para que no se caiga el alimento, con estos productos de apoyo trabajamos la funcionalidad del miembro superior en una de las tareas más importantes para el ser humano como es la alimentación

actuation-operation.title: Adaptive Silverware Handle
actuation-operation.summary:
This is my entry for the Assistive Technology Challenge.

Millions of people are dealing with a verity of issues with their hands from arthritis, injury, or other illness. Such issues can make their silverware impossible to use.

These adaptive handles are designed to help those with dexterity issues use their ordinary household silverware without having to buy expensive sets from a commercial company. These handles will work for anyone with weak grip, no grip (because it slips between your fingers) or thumb amputees.

With a couple rubber bands, you can attach your silverware to the base of this handle. This will let you use your silverware without a strong grip or thumb.

These were designed by Stan Baldwin & Ty Lendit for #AssistiveTech the Assistive Technology Challenge.

actuation-operation.title: Sockinator (Sock aid)
actuation-operation.summary:
This 3D-printable device is for the Assistive Technology Challenge.

When I read about that challenge, I thought that I need to take part in that challenge and design something that is useful for several people.

For a lot of people with disabilities or elderly people it is difficult to do „easy“ things like getting dressed, without the help of others. Many people don’t even think how hard it can be to get on your socks, if you can’t get down to your feet. I first recognized that, when I visited my grandma. She can still do it herself, but it is very difficult, especially as she is ill right now and doesn’t feel that well. But on the other hand she also doesn’t want help (it is also a part of freedom, if you can get dressed yourself and also when you want)

I designed the Sockinator to help people to put on their socks or stockings themselves or for their day keepers to make it easier. Right now I have only one size, but I planned to make more versions, so it fits for everyone. If you have additional suggestions on how I could improve the Sockinator, feel free to send them to me.

You can adjust the angle of the rod and use the device in two ways.

  1. You have the rod on the right side: You put the sock inside the round part and pull the inside around the walls, so the sock is wide open and you can put your foot through it.
  2. You have the rod on the left side: You just put the sock around the part. Like that the device just opens the sock.

You can try both ways and see what works best for you…

To assemble the device you need:

1x M4 hex head screw min 20mm
1x M4 hex nut
1x part 1
1x part 2
4x part 3
1x part 4

The nail clipper holder is a low-cost, 3D-printed handheld tool that makes clipping nails a less strenuous task for people with limited finger dexterity. It features a large force applicator so users can clip their nails by pushing down on it with their palm or hand.

July 2020 update: combined the clipper holder and force applicator into one design so no hardware is required.


Volunteer your 3D printing skills to help people with disabilities in your community!

Makers Making Change is an initiative of the Neil Squire Society, a Canadian non-profit that helps people with disabilities.

We are committed to creating a network of volunteer makers who support people with disabilities in their communities through 3D printing assistive devices. Check out our library of free, open-source assistive technologies with parts and build instructions.

This is a simple thing that slips over the end of the upper lever arm of a nail clipper, to give you a better grip. At least for me, it keeps my thumb from sliding down the lever arm, so it is easier to clip my finger nails. I was surprised at how much difference it made..

The OpenSCAD file is entirely parametric, but I think most nail clippers can be accommodated by changing just two input parameters, as explained in the OpenSCAD file.

The sketch (pdf file) shows at least most of the parameters and variables, and a very rough sketch of the thing. It's a scan of the un-cleaned-up sketch I used during the final design stage.

Do you like to read while you eat? Do you often have a cookbook open while making recipes? Do you have an open manual while building a 3D printer or other device? Are you frustrated with these books closing on you, losing your page and disturbing your activity?

This device will solve these problems. Easy to print, easy to assemble, and easy to use, just push down the levers and insert your book, and the Hands-Free Book holder will keep the book open in exactly the spot you want!

I love to read while eating, and I grew frustrated with the book closing on me if I needed two hands while eating. This holder allows me to enjoy my reading lunches in peace.

actuation-operation.summary:
Awesome Toothpaste Dispenser

This unique design/creation allows you to distribute toothpaste directly onto your toothbrush. It also acts as an additional toothbrush stand or holder.

• The toothpaste extruder can be locked in place to prevent tubes from rolling out.
• Additional toothbrush holders can be printed depending on the amount of users.
• The toothpaste extruder/roller can also be used separately as a portable version.

The design was printed and tested using Ultimaker Cura 3.6.0, with the following settings (PLA):

Base & Toothbrush Holders
layer height: 0.24
Infill: 35%
Supports: No

Stand
layer height: 0.20
Infill: 35%
Supports: Yes

Extruder & Extruder Shaft
layer height: 0.20
Infill: 35%
Supports: No

• The total print time can be expected at around 11 hours.

actuation-operation.title: Affordable Prosthetic for people without Fingers
actuation-operation.summary:
This multipurpose hand prosthetic is designed for people without fingers so that they could perform some basic activities. While there are plenty of such projects online, they are mostly either too simple or are too expensive and too complex for cheap mass production. As an Indian, I have designed this especially for people living in poor countries where this prosthetic can be distributed very cost effectively by health agencies.

The arm clamp is detachable so that you can make your custom clamp according to your comfort and needs.
Note: The model I printed came out quite bad because of my broken printer. I have made quite a lot of design changes. However, I haven't had the time to test those changes. So it would be amazing if anyone could print this and give me some feedback in the comments.
With this, people without fingers should be able to:
Use Pens and Pencils
Use Cutlery
Use Toothbrush
Added features:
Hold cups
Hold bags
Use touchscreens
Use 4mm Hex tool bits and interchangeable screwdriver sets
I got the inspiration after stumbling different assistive devices on Thinigiverse .
I am also uploading a version without the cup holder.

actuation-operation.title: Lever for Pressing Buttons
actuation-operation.summary:
This lever is designed to help anyone with hand mobility issues to press buttons on devices like electric toothbrushes, shavers, trimmers etc. Because buttons are both raised and inset depending on the device, I opted for using an M5 16 mm to 20 mm screw and nut to act as an offset. This way it is fully adjustable to ensure the lever can be used on any button.

The simple design allows it to attach easily with a zip tie. If the surface allows the zip tie to turn once attached, put an elastic band or a piece of Dycem under the rounded part of the lever where it touches the appliance. This will create a nonslip surface once the zip tie is secured.

actuation-operation.summary:
Der Schrank in meinem Büro hat keinen Knauf und wird nur durch einen kleinen Schlüssel geöffnet. Da dieser echt scharfe Kanten hat habe ich diesen „Überzieher“ konstruiert.

A closet in my office has only a key to open it, no handle. Therefore I designed this little knob to pull it over the key.

This is my own design of an open assistive technology device which allows people with missing digits and/or reduced digital dexterity or grip strength to insert and turn keys in locks.

For people with arthritis this device can be operated with little to no grip strength.

For people with missing digits and/or reduced digital dexterity this device can be operated with a minimum of one finger and can accommodate a maximum of three fingers in the device but you can obviously use you whole hand if you want.

The device can fit comfortably in a pocket and with the fluorescent color it lends itself to easy identification even in low light settings.

In addition to the 3-d print, I use one 4mm bolt, two 4mm nuts and one 4mm washer to secure a wide variety of keys within the recessed area of the device. Behind the handle of the key is a short slot which allows for keys with varying handle sizes and handle hole locations. With a small modification a key loop can be added so that it can be attached to a traditional lanyard or keychain.

I have personally tested this device as of 26 Oct 2016 and it works quite well if I do say so myself.

actuation-operation.title: Key turner with lever handle
actuation-operation.summary:
Key handles for people with wrist pain or fine motor problems that make it hard to grasp and turn keys. Three different versions: the oval and diamond shapes fit two common types of keys, and one requested by a friend who has a ridiculously oversized key for her classroom. There's a handle and a spacer, and you screw it together with the key sandwiched between the spacer and the handle. The two common keys use the same spacer but the comically large classroom key needed its own spacer. I used a M2.5 screw and nut.

I recommend printing these on their side, with the flat L shape of the handle against the bed and the key oriented vertically. That will let you print with minimal (or no) supports. Use a relatively high infill percentage for durability since it will be taking torque on a regular basis.

I've also included the fusion 360 files so you can modify it to suit your needs. Alas, Past Rowanon didn't use good design principles so it may be easier for you to start from scratch anyway.

Modeled from scratch but inspired by dma678's design. That's the first key turner I've seen with the lever, which is a bulky but game changing addition. I wanted something that fit the keys a bit better and kept them from wiggling around in the holder.

actuation-reach.title: faucet extension (rotatable version)
actuation-reach.summary:
There are some designs for the faucet extension that you can find in here but all of them are fixed in the faucet once you attach it. I want to make a version that can be rotated in case I need water for drinking for example.

This design has 2 parts, one to be fixed to the faucet (faucetExtensionFixedV2b.STL) and the movable part (faucetExtensionMovedV2c.STL) can rotate about the first one. The cross section of my faucet is 11.5x25mm. I added the FreeCAD file (faucetExtensionFixedV2.FCStd) of the fixed part in case you want to edit to fit your faucet.

If you could, print the fixed part with flexible material. I tried both PLA and TPE and the flexible one fit much better.

constraint.title: Child Safety Stove Knob Protectors - customizable
constraint.summary:
This is something I came up with to help keep small hands from turning the knobs on the stove. Either turning the burners on and burning down the house or turning the burners up and scorching dinner. The stove knobs are protected all around by a wall of plastic. The knob-protectors are linked together in groups of two to keep the child from rotating the protector around. This piece is held in place by the plastic nut behind the knob.

The piece is designed in OpenSCAD and is customizable. There is a setting for diameter of the inside hole, the knob's diameter, thickness, knob spacing, the diagonal cutout, etc.

I have some similar child safety stove knob covers for a gas range at my house. Two of them have broken however and I wanted to try to make a replacement. They broke where they are hinged(when the oven door hit them). So this design can be removed and set on the counter, then reinstalled. I first tried to make it with pieces that snapped together, but the fit wasn't good enough to stop it from being removed by a child. I then switched to the current design with threads and it seems to fit just right. This seems strong enough for a young child, but out of PLA it can be broken by force. Shout out to the guys at 3D Printing Today Podcast, I discovred Fusion 360 after one of there podcasts and I love it!

indication-visual.title: Stickable label holder
indication-visual.summary:
This is an alternative label holder made from my previous design - the shelf label holder. This one can be glued to any flat surface using double-sided adhesive tape. The top and bottom edges of the holder are flattened so any items can slide over it. After attaching it just slide the label into the front slot and you are done.

As in the previous design, the default length is 60 mm but it can be stretched freely to any length. The whole shape is repeatable along the Z-axis.

The label can be made of paper or any other material. The slit is 1.5 mm wide so thicker labels can also be used. Bear in mind that the edges that hold the label limit the visible part by 1 mm on both sides.

actuation-operation.title: Armie - Hands-Free Handle
actuation-operation.summary:
Armie is a 3D printed hands-free handle, designed to prevent the spreading of COVID-19. The virus is said to live on hard surfaces for up to 72 hours, within that time many people may have touched the handles of the drawers or doors in your place of work. Armie promotes people to use their arms to open doors, as the user is less likely to transmit the virus using this method.

The device is designed to fit on most handle profiles, however, we are aware it may not fit onto all handles. Armie requires a minimum of two cable ties to successfully secure the 3D print to the handle. There is a left and right-hand version of the Armie, please print according to which side of the door your handle is situated. Installation instructions on how to install Armie can be found within the project folder.

Together we can help prevent the spreading of COVID-19. Please get in touch if you have any feedback regarding the design or how it could be improved.

printcity@mmu.ac.uk

PrintCity Team

constraint.title: Child deterrent device
constraint.summary: Our 2 year old recently learned how to open the refrigerator...

actuation-operation.summary:
My name is Prasad because of Muscular dystrophy I use battery operated wheelchair ottobock B 500. Muscular dystrophy id degenerative muscle disorder and have lost my ability to drink and eat by myself .
I was looking for glass holder for my wheelchair I could not find glass holder which suited me my friends using wheelchair were also looking for something which could be a hands free drinking solution
My mentor gave me a 3D printer and told me to try this technology . At first I was thinking what's the big deal in 3D printing why people are saying it's the technology of future? but when I started seeing objects printing whole lot of Ideas started pouring up in my mind and I thought of making glass holder using it.
My design ideas were.
1.)The glass holder should be able to hold different types of glasses and tins around diameter of 75 centimetres
2.) It should be in front so that the person can view what he is drinking.
3.) There should be no tools required to install the glass holder.
4.) When not in use the glass holder can be easily removed.
5.) Other attachments like mobile holder could be easily added . Position of mobile holder should be ideal for Google Voice commands, speakerphone, clicking pictures through voice commands.
6.) The glass holder should be compact and easily disassembled during travel .

These prevent "lever" style door knobs/handles from being pulled down, they can only be pulled up to open the door. There's a slot for a captive M4 nut and a single bolt to clamp down on the handle.

This is corner protection to 8mm glass table with sharp edges. This could prevent children to hurt themselve while learning how to walk / run. This easy invention saved a zilion times cute heads of my toddlers.

You can scale this design in Z axis (before rotating) so you can make it fit other thicknes that suits to your table.

Use this equation:

zasf = h / 8

where:

zasf - Z axis scale factor - that you need to scale object (only in Z axis! other axies should be locked down)

h - your table thickness in mm [for example 10mm]

so, if your table is 10mm thick you got:

zasf = 10/8 = 1,25

so you have to scale up 25% my design in Z axis to fit this protector to your table.

If you happen to have the same fridge as me, there are two screws put into the door surface right between the upper freezer and lower fridge. I believe they are so you can swap the direction the fridge opens from side to side. They are mounted just right to add a small flat panel with some cutouts to the side that allow you to insert a rope, with a knot on the end, to "lock" the fridge from inquisitive toddlers.

In the photos, you can see some scrap material used as a rope however I later picked up some ~3mm paracord and found this would work well too (and it looks a lot better too although once you start safety proofing for kids, looks are pretty low down on the list after a year or two).

(and yes, I see a bit of cleaning on the fridge door is needed!)

I first tried to make it with pieces that snapped together, but the fit wasn't good enough to stop it from being removed by a child. I then switched to the current design with threads and it seems to fit just right. This seems strong enough for a young child, but out of PLA it can be broken by force. The stove knobs are protected all around by a wall of plastic. The knob-protectors are linked together in groups of two to keep the child from rotating the protector around. This piece is held in place by the plastic nut behind the knob.

The piece is designed in OpenSCAD and is customizable. There is a setting for diameter of the inside hole, the knob's diameter, thickness, knob spacing, the diagonal cutout, etc.

constraint.summary: Prevents your child from turning on your oven and/or changing the temperature. Snaps right on to the oven handle if your oven looks like mine. Tested successfully on a 12 months old baby.

For some reason, LG washing and dryers child protect function does not block the power button this has caused a lot of issues at home. We have tried more nice looking design but 1,5 years old will bypass those without a big issue. The design is made so if accidental drops water down it will not be forced into the power button but be able to be drained out from the outlets.

Project & Support Moved

This project and it's continued support have moved to Josef Prusa's https://www.printables.com/. I will no longer be updating items here, and may not respond to comments or questions.

Please visit the link below for the latest version:
https://www.printables.com/model/157127-window-blind-cord-child-proofing

Summary

Magnetic detachable window blinds cord hanger. Keeps the cord from your blinds up off the ground for child proofing, robot vacuums, or whatever other reason you want cords to be managed and up out of the way.

I designed these to replace the commercial options out there that cost upwards of $8-10 dollars per window, which is crazy for some plastic and a few magnets.

Uses cheap, ceramic round fridge magnets that can be readily found on Amazon or eBay in packs of 100 for about $8. Magnet size is 18 mm x 5 mm (though the magnets tend to be slightly smaller than their stated dimensions and the model reflects this).

Each window will need 3X 18 mm x 5 mm ceramic magnet.
